snippet: Police officials will step up law enforcement as 200,000 to 300,000 visitors pour into private clubs this Memorial Day weekend....
abstract: Police officials in Miami Beach will step up law enforcement as 200,000 to 300,000 visitors pour into city for Urban Beach Week to hear some of the country's leading hip hop artists and DJ's; loosely organized event has had issues with violence in the past, and local residents often head to the mainland for its duration. Photo (M)
lead_paragraph: MIAMI BEACH -- This small city is accustomed to big events. But every Urban Beach Week, residents and businesses take in a collective deep breath and do not exhale until it's over. Since 2001, hundreds of thousands of young hip-hop devotees from around the country have descended on the South Beach neighborhood for Memorial Day weekend to hear some of country's leading artists and D.J.'s. As the visitors converge, a reverse migration ensues: Rresidents, beaten down by the traffic and chaos of the event, hop in their cars en masse and head to the mainland for a few days.

headline.main: As Hip-Hop Devotees Come In, Many Miami Beach Residents Prepare to Leave

snippet: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week....
lead_paragraph: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week. SAN ANTONIO

headline.main: GTT

snippet: Texas A&M University’s program in Doha is experiencing growing enrollment and a burgeoning research effort....
lead_paragraph: DOHA, Qatar -- On the day before his college graduation here, Thamer al-Kuwari wore the white robe and headdress that are customary for men in his native Qatar. But on his finger, he wore something special: an Aggie Ring, the traditional accessory of a proud Texas A&M University alumnus, which he was about to become. Mr. Kuwari's enthusiasm for Texas A&M may, at first blush, seem strong for someone who spent a mere four months studying in College Station. ''Ever since I joined the Aggie family,'' he said, ''I've loved it with every part of my heart.''

headline.main: Class of 2012 in Qatar Savors the College Station Connection

snippet: Patrick J. Fitzgerald, who oversaw the prosecution of Gov. Rod R. Blagojevich, expressed regret for saying that the governor’s conduct would “make Lincoln roll over in his grave.”...
abstract: Outgoing United States attorney Patrick J Fitzgerald, expresses regret for comment he made in 2008 criticizing former Illinois Gov Rod R Blagojevich; Fitzgerald had said that Balgojevich's behavior would 'make Lincoln roll over in his grave.' (M)/
lead_paragraph: A day after announcing he would resign as the United States attorney for the Northern District of Illinois, Patrick J. Fitzgerald, who oversaw the prosecution of Gov. Rod R. Blagojevich, expressed regret for saying that the governor's conduct would ''make Lincoln roll over in his grave.'' Mr. Fitzgerald was criticized for making the comment after the 2008 arrest of Mr. Blagojevich, who was eventually convicted of trying to sell Barack Obama's vacated Senate seat. ''I probably could have had a colder shower, a little more sleep and some decaf,'' Mr. Fitzgerald said Thursday at a news conference. ''Having said that, I did get grief over it, and what bothers me about that, frankly, is I don't want it to overshadow what the agents did in that case.'' Mr. Fitzgerald, whose other high-profile prosecutions include public corruption charges against former Gov. George Ryan and a C.I.A. leak case against I. Lewis Libby Jr., the former chief of staff for Vice President Dick Cheney, said he would consider other government work, but ruled out running for office. ''I'm not wired to campaign for anything or run for elected office,'' he said. ''Period.''

headline.main: Illinois: Departing Prosecutor Has a Regret

snippet: A still-tough economy compounded by stinging transportation costs has clipped wallets in places like Tacoma....
abstract: Gas prices in Washington State are far higher than in the rest of the country, soaring 32 cents per gallon from the period a year earlier; increase, due in part to a refinery bottleneck, has compounded economic hardship for consumers in the region. Photo (M)l
lead_paragraph: TACOMA, Wash. -- A lot has come down the pike since the summer of 2008, which for many Americans may already feel like the closed chapter of an old book. But here on the West Coast there is an unhappy echo: gasoline prices. One thin dime separates the current average price of a regular gallon of gas from Tacoma's historic high of $4.37 that was set in late June 2008. And while most Americans have caught a break over the last year, with the average price for a gallon of regular falling 15 cents compared with this time in 2011, in Western Washington it was up 32 cents as of Thursday, according to the Oil Price Information Service, a petroleum-pricing research group.

headline.main: In Western Washington, Gas Prices Buck the Trend

snippet: The unstaffed SpaceX Dragon capsule performed a practice lap near the International Space Station and checked out its communication and navigation systems....
abstract: SpaceX Dragon, the world's first private supply ship, passes critical test as it prepares to dock with the International Space Station. (S)
lead_paragraph: The world's first private supply ship flew tantalizingly close to the International Space Station on Thursday, passing a critical test in advance of Friday's actual docking. The unstaffed SpaceX Dragon capsule performed a practice lap around the orbiting laboratory and checked out its communication and navigation systems. Officials at NASA and the Space Exploration Technologies Corporation, which built and launched the ship, declared the rendezvous a success. Dragon is the first American vessel to visit the space station since NASA's shuttles retired last summer and the first private spacecraft to ever try a delivery. It is carrying 1,000 pounds of provisions.

headline.main: Supply Ship Passes Test Before Docking

snippet: Except for a few requests for exhibits, and clarification on when they might quit for the day, the only indication of the jurors’ mood comes from their appearances in the courtroom....
abstract: Jurors in the federal corruption case against former Sen John Edwards enter their fifth day of deliberation; request to review several pieces of evidence related to the core charges of campaign finance fraud. (M)
lead_paragraph: GREENSBORO, N.C. -- After five days, the jurors in the federal corruption case against former Senator John Edwards continue to grapple with the six charges against him. Their deliberations began last Friday, with a request for some exhibits and office supplies. Except for a few more requests for exhibits, and clarification from the judge on when they might quit for the day, the only indication of their mood comes from their brief daily appearances in the courtroom, where spectators can try to decipher facial expressions or body languages.

headline.main: On Day 5, Edwards Jury Plows Through The Exhibits

snippet: State Representative Vicki Truitt and Giovanni Capriglione, her primary challenger, are locked in a tight campaign battle, and accusations are flying....
lead_paragraph: SOUTHLAKE -- Both supporters and detractors of State Representative Vicki Truitt, a seven-term Republican, agree that her nickname, Bulldog, fits. Those working for her re-election say she represents her constituents in this cluster of wealthy neighborhoods between Fort Worth and Dallas with relentless determination. For fans of Giovanni Capriglione, the primary challenger, Ms. Truitt's nickname supports their view of her as stubborn and confrontational. They also say she is not conservative enough to represent the most Republican district in the largest Republican county in Texas.

headline.main: In Primary, One Pair Takes Off The Gloves

snippet: In an attempt to stop the illegal sale of benefit cards, a proposed rule would allow states to demand formal explanations from people who seek replacements for them more than three times a year....
abstract: Agriculture Dept proposes rule that would crack down on food stamp recipients who illegally sell their benefit cards and then ask for replacements. (S)/
lead_paragraph: The Agriculture Department wants to crack down on food stamp recipients who illegally sell their benefit cards, sometimes even in the open, on eBay or Craigslist, and then ask for replacements. The proposed rule would allow states to demand formal explanations from people who seek replacements more than three times a year. Those who do not comply could be denied further cards. ''Up to this point, the state's hands have been tied unless they absolutely suspected fraudulent activity,'' said Kevin Concannon, a department undersecretary.

headline.main: Proposed Rule Aims at Food Stamp Cheaters

snippet: White midshipmen refused to sit next to Mr. Brown, racial epithets were whispered behind his back and fellow plebes barred him from joining the choir....
abstract: Wesley A Brown, retired Navy lieutenant commander who was the first black graduate of the United States Naval Academy, dies at age 85. Photo (M)/
lead_paragraph: Wesley A. Brown, a retired Navy lieutenant commander who endured intense racial hazing to become the first black graduate of the United States Naval Academy, died Tuesday in Silver Spring, Md. He was 85. The cause was cancer, said his wife, Crystal.

headline.main: Wesley Brown, 85, Pioneer As Black Naval Graduate

snippet: A measure to prevent drug shortages and to accelerate federal review of new and generic medications won broad support, with a similar bill on a fast track to approval in the House....
abstract: Senate passes a major bipartisan bill to prevent drug shortages and to speed federal approval of lifesaving medicines, including lower-cost generic versions of biotechnology products; similar bill, strongly supported by Pres Obama, consumer groups and pharmaceutical companies, is on a fast track to approval in the House. Photo (M)
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON -- The Senate passed a major bipartisan bill on Thursday to prevent drug shortages and to speed federal approval of lifesaving medicines, including lower-cost generic versions of biotechnology products. A similar bill is on a fast track to approval in the House, perhaps as early as next week. President Obama, consumer groups and pharmaceutical companies strongly support the legislation.

headline.main: Senate Backs Bipartisan Bill to Speed Drugs and Avert Shortages

snippet: Lt. Gov. David Dewhurst’s departure for Washington would clear a space on a political escalator that has been more or less stationary for the last decade....
lead_paragraph: Ross Ramsey, the managing editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for the Tribune. Lt. Gov. David Dewhurst is carrying a lot of political hopes and dreams on his shoulders in his United States Senate campaign.

headline.main: In Austin Choreography, Dewhurst Must Hit His Mark

snippet: In Arizona, a makeshift camp at a high school sustains 1,160 firefighters spread across three outposts in the mountains and 498 other workers....
abstract: Spring Valley Journal; makeshift camp at Mayer High School in Spring Valley, Ariz, sustains 1,160 firefighters who are waging a protracted wildfire battle in the area; exceptionally low humidity and record-high temperatures in the region signal a potentially devastating fire season. Map, Photos (M)
lead_paragraph: SPRING VALLEY, Ariz. -- A long stretch in the burning wilderness is all it takes to redefine the meaning of life's greatest pleasures. To Jon Crane, it was running an electric toothbrush around his teeth. To J. J. Rue, it was stepping on flat paved ground. They had 45 minutes at the camp here before heading out again to dig ditches, topple trees, scrape the rugged soil bare and set all of the debris ablaze -- a counterintuitive strategy of fighting fire with fire. Mr. Crane and Mr. Rue, members of a charmingly named squad, the Smokey Bear Hotshots out of Ruidoso, N.M., swooped on the makeshift kitchen, snatching a hearty eggs-and-bacon breakfast. Then, it was on to the makeshift showers, where 6,000 gallons of water would be consumed that day.

headline.main: At a Wildfire Base Camp, Logistics and Pop-Tarts

snippet: Both parties foresee an election lift in quick action on Bush-era tax legislation....
abstract: Both parties in the House and the Senate are eager to vote for their respective versions of an extension of the Bush-era tax cuts, far in advance of the deadline; believe the vote has the potential to shore up their election-year narratives and give them a boost at the polls. (M)
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON -- It is a maxim in Congress these days: If high-profile legislation affecting millions of Americans is about to expire, deal with it at the last possible second, preferably with rancor. But a major exception is in the offing with the Bush-era tax cuts, which are set to lapse on Jan 1. Both parties in the House and the Senate are eager, perhaps even giddy, at the prospect of voting for their respective versions of an extension of the cuts this summer, well before the due date.

headline.main: An Often Procrastinating Congress Is Raring at the Gate on Tax Cuts

snippet: The Army private, Pfc. Naser Jason Abdo, said the bombing of a restaurant filled with other soldiers was his religious mission....
abstract: Pfc Naser Jason Abdo, a Muslim, is convicted in a plot to blow up a restaurant full of troops from Fort Hod as part of a religious mission to get 'justice' for the people of Iraq and Afghanistan; is found guilty of six charges, including attempting to use a weapon of mass destruction. (M)
lead_paragraph: WACO, Tex. (AP) -- A Muslim soldier was convicted Thursday in a plot to blow up a restaurant full of troops from Fort Hood as part of a religious mission to get ''justice'' for the people of Iraq and Afghanistan. A District Court jury found the soldier, Pfc. Naser Jason Abdo, 22, guilty of six charges, including attempting to use a weapon of mass destruction, attempted murder of United States officers or employees, and possessing a weapon in furtherance of a federal crime of violence.

headline.main: Soldier Guilty in Plot to Bomb A Restaurant Near Ft. Hood

snippet: Unlike past presidents at this stage in the campaign, President Obama has not hesitated to engage his rival....
abstract: Pres Obama is making direct attacks on Mitt Romney more than five months before the election; incumbents have traditionally avoided directed confrontation so early, for fear of appearing as a candidate rather than a president. Photos (M)d
lead_paragraph: DES MOINES -- With the general election campaign now under way, one thing has become clear: There will be no Rose Garden strategy for President Obama. If past incumbents have been reluctant to directly engage opponents this early in an election year for fear of looking like a candidate rather than a president, Mr. Obama has tossed aside convention. No simply leaving it to the vice president or the campaign staff, no waiting until summer, no dancing around with oblique phrases like ''my opponent.''

headline.main: Obama Takes Early Leap Into Direct Engagement on Campaign Trail

snippet: Berkeley Police Chief Michael Meehan is under scrutiny for using 10 officers, some on overtime, to search for his teenage son’s stolen iPhone....
lead_paragraph: Berkeley Police Chief Michael Meehan is under scrutiny for using 10 officers, some on overtime, to search for his teenage son's stolen iPhone. Chief Meehan told The Oakland Tribune on Wednesday that no preferential treatment was given when officers, including three detectives and a sergeant who each logged two hours of overtime, searched for the phone, which has a tracking device and was taken from a school locker in January. A police report was never written and the officers' search led them to parts of neighboring Oakland, unknown to that city's Police Department. Chief Meehan said that field supervisors decide how many officers to put on a case, and that the search was handled properly. ''I think it was worth it,'' he said, noting that 11 officers responded in two other cases of stolen iPhones. His son's phone was not found.

headline.main: California: 10 Officers On Trail of An iPhone

byline.original: By ASHLEY PARKER; Michael Barbaro contributed reporting from Philadelphia

snippet: For Mitt Romney’s campaign, the scrutiny of his time at Bain Capital poses a delicate challenge: not only must he defend himself against attacks from President Obama, but he also must try to cast the lessons he learned there as a testament to hi...
abstract: Mitt Romney's tenure at Bain Capital has become a complex campaign issue, as the Obama camp tries to use it underscore Romney's image as an out-of-touch multimillionaire; Romney is attempting to undercut this message, saying his private sector experience has equipped him to manage the economy. Photo (M)
lead_paragraph: Mitt Romney's campaign sees the time he spent at Bain Capital, the private equity firm he co-founded and ran for more than a decade, as a positive experience that highlights his leadership skills and his ability to turn around companies and create jobs. President Obama's campaign, meanwhile, views Mr. Romney's Bain Capital years as a political liability that underscores his image as an out-of-touch multimillionaire, concerned only with turning profits for his wealthy investors. For Mr. Romney's campaign, the scrutiny of his time at Bain poses a delicate challenge: not only must he defend himself against attacks coming from the president, but he also must try to cast Bain and the lessons he learned there as a testament to his management skills.

headline.main: Both Campaigns Seize on Romney's Years at Bain

byline.original: By CHARLIE SAVAGE; Michael S. Schmidt contributed reporting

snippet: While the prosecutors were “reckless” in their handling of Senator Ted Stevens’s 2008 corruption trial, they will not be fired because their mistakes were deemed unintentional....
abstract: Justice Department will temporarily suspend prosecutors Joseph Bottini and James Goeke for reckless professional misconduct during the botched 2008 corruption trial of Sen Ted Stevens. (M)
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON -- The Justice Department has found that two prosecutors involved in the botched 2008 corruption trial of Senator Ted Stevens engaged in ''reckless professional misconduct,'' but it stopped short of firing the men, saying their mistakes were not intentional. In a cover letter to a 672-page report provided to Congress on Thursday, alongside additional attachments and findings, the Justice Department said the two prosecutors would be suspended without pay -- Joseph Bottini for 40 days, and James Goeke for 15 days.

headline.main: Prosecutors Suspended In '08 Trial Of a Senator

snippet: The Senate rejected dueling Democratic and Republican plans on Thursday for averting a July 1 doubling of interest rates on federal college loans for 7.4 million students, pushing back efforts to resolve the problem until next month....
abstract: Senate rejects dueling Democratic and Republican plans for averting a doubling of interest rates on federal college loans that will affect 7.4 million students; separate measures both fall short of the 60 votes needed for approval, pushing back the decision until after the Memorial Day recess. (M)
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON (AP) -- The Senate rejected dueling Democratic and Republican plans on Thursday for averting a July 1 doubling of interest rates on federal college loans for 7.4 million students, pushing back efforts to resolve the problem until next month. Before heading off for a 10-day Memorial Day recess, senators voted 62 to 34 against the Republican package and 51 to 43 for the Democratic version, with each falling short of the 60 votes needed for approval. The votes, largely along party lines, were preordained, but the exercise gave lawmakers from each party a chance to show they favor easing students' financial burdens -- and offered potential grist for campaign ads accusing the other side of opposing the effort.

headline.main: Senate Stalls on Legislation For Student Loan Relief

snippet: The justices split over whether the constitutional protection against double jeopardy barred such reprosecutions....
abstract: Supreme Court rules that a criminal defendant may be retried even though the jury in his first trial had unanimously rejected the most serious charges against him; court votes 6 to 3, with justices split over whether the constitutional protection against double jeopardy bars such reprosecutions. (M)
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON -- The Supreme Courtruled on Thursday that a criminal defendant may be retried even though the jury in his first trial had unanimously rejected the most serious charges against him. The vote was 6 to 3, with the justices split over whether the constitutional protection against double jeopardy barred such reprosecutions. The case arose from the death in 2007 of a 1-year-old Arkansas boy, Matthew McFadden Jr., from a head injury he suffered while at home with his mother's boyfriend, Alex Blueford. The prosecution said Mr. Blueford had slammed Matthew into a mattress; Mr. Blueford said he had accidentally knocked the boy to the floor.

headline.main: Justices Allow Retrial On Rejected Charges

snippet: The video game company of the former Boston Red Sox pitcher Curt Schilling, 38 Studios, notified workers of the “nonvoluntary and nondisciplinary” layoffs on Thursday....
abstract: Thirty-Eight Studios, video game company founded by former Boston Red Sox pitcher Curt Schilling, lays off its entire staff; layoffs follow company's failure to make a payment on $75 million loan guarantee by the state of Rhode Island. (M).
lead_paragraph: The video game company of the former Boston Red Sox pitcher Curt Schilling has laid off its entire staff. An e-mail sent by the company, 38 Studios, to workers says they were notified of the ''nonvoluntary and nondisciplinary'' layoffs on Thursday. The company moved from Massachusetts in 2010 after Rhode Island offered a $75 million loan guarantee that officials said would bring jobs and tax revenue. The company was late this month on a $1.1 million payment to the state economic development agency. The agency's vice chairwoman, Helena Foulkes, and a member, Stephen Lane, resigned Thursday. The state could be responsible for some of the company's debt if it collapses.

headline.main: Rhode Island: Ex-pitcher's Staff Is Laid Off

abstract: Defense Dept confirms death of one American service member in Afghanistan. (S)2
lead_paragraph: The Department of Defense has identified 1,965 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American recently: FIELDS, Arronn D., 27, Specialist, Army; Terre Haute, Ind., 81st Troop Command, Indiana National Guard.

headline.main: Names of the Dead

snippet: More than three decades after private equity burst onto the scene in the merger mania of the 1980s, the industry remains as mysterious and controversial as ever....
abstract: Relationship between the private equity industry and job creation is far more nuanced than portraits painted in advertisements for the Romney and Obama campaigns. Photos (M)
lead_paragraph: In an advertisement released this month by President Obama's campaign, Mitt Romney and the private equity firm he co-founded, Bain Capital, are painted as vampires. They sucked the lifeblood out of GST Steel in the 1990s, which pushed it into bankruptcy, destroying jobs and eliminating pensions. In a quick counterattack, the Romney campaign released an ad that highlighted the robust job growth at another Bain investment, the manufacturing company Steel Dynamics. The ad featured employees who said the investment had helped them achieve the American dream.

headline.main: Political Ads Don't Tell Full Story on Private Equity

byline.original: By NICHOLAS CONFESSORE; Jennifer Steinhauer contributed reporting

snippet: Attacks by President Obama’s campaign against Mitt Romney’s work in private equity have strained the relationship between Democrats and the financial industry....
lead_paragraph: Last week, a few dozen hedge fund and investment executives arrived at the Park Avenue home of Hamilton E. James, president of the private equity firm Blackstone. Each had paid $35,800 to spend two hours at a fund-raiser with President Obama, but the timing proved awkward: A few hours earlier, Mr. Obama's campaign had begun a blistering attack on Mitt Romney's career in private equity, the same business in which Mr. James has earned his many millions. ''Campaigns do what campaigns have to do,'' Mr. James later told friends. But not everyone was as forgiving. ''People were incredulous,'' said one person who attended the dinner. ''They could have waited a week.''

headline.main: Bain Strategy Holds Pitfalls For President

snippet: A government official said that the evidence did not support charging Lucie Zeeko Marigot, 41, with interfering with a flight crew. Ms. Marigot is being turned over to Customs and Border Protection and will be sent home....
abstract: Lucie Zeeko Marigot, French woman accused of causing a US Airways flight from Paris en route to North Carolina to be diverted to Maine by claiming she had a surgically implanted device, will not be charged. (M)3
lead_paragraph: A French woman accused of causing a US Airways flight from Paris en route to North Carolina to be diverted to Maine by claiming she had a surgically implanted device will not be charged, officials said Wednesday. United States Attorney Thomas Delahanty II told a federal magistrate judge that the evidence did not support charging Lucie Zeeko Marigot, 41, with interfering with a flight crew. She is being turned over to Customs and Border Protection and will be sent home, he said. Ms. Marigot, who speaks only French, gave a note to a flight attendant and a book she had written. She said that she had been wronged by a group of doctors and that she had something inside her that was ''out of control,'' Mr. Delahanty said. She also said she wanted medical help from President Obama and the American people, he said. Two doctors aboard the aircraft examined Ms. Marigot and found no evidence of an incision, and the F.B.I. concluded there was no danger.

headline.main: Maine: No Charges Against Woman Who Caused Flight To Be Diverted

snippet: The jurors, who ended their fourth day of deliberations on Wednesday, are being asked to determine whether donors gave money with the “purpose to influence an election.”...
abstract: Essential question facing the jury in John Edwards federal corruption trial is whether or not funds he used to cover up his extramarital affair should be considered campaign contributions; jury, now in its fourth day of deliberation, is likely to be influenced by the expansive definition of campaign contributions articulated by Judge Catherine C Eagles. Photo (M)
lead_paragraph: GREENSBORO, N.C. -- Legal analysts awaiting a verdict in the John Edwards federal corruption trial say the judge's interpretation of the law could shape what the jurors might ultimately decide. Although jurors have been weighing the complex and tawdry story of a concealed mistress, Rielle Hunter, and the child she and Mr. Edwards conceived -- and a cover-up financed with money from wealthy friends -- the question of guilt or innocence hinges on a single question: Did the money amount to gifts -- as Mr. Edwards contends -- or illegal and improperly reported campaign contributions, as the government contends?

headline.main: How Judge Views Law Might Sway the Jurors At the Edwards Trial

snippet: The aide, Howard Brooks, was charged Wednesday with one count of making a false statement to the F.B.I. about giving money to Sulaimon Brown, a 2010 District of Columbia mayoral candidate....
abstract: Howard Brooks, former campaign aide to District of Columbia Mayor Vincent Gray, is charged with making a false statement to the FBI about giving money to Sulaimon Brown, a 2010 District of Columbia mayoral candidate. (M)
lead_paragraph: A second former campaign aide to the District of Columbia's mayor, Vincent Gray, is facing federal charges relating to money given to another candidate. The aide, Howard Brooks, was charged Wednesday with one count of making a false statement to the F.B.I. about giving money to Sulaimon Brown, a 2010 mayoral candidate. Mr. Brown has said he was paid to criticize the incumbent, Adrian Fenty, who was seeking re-election. On Tuesday, the man who was assistant treasurer in Mr. Gray's campaign pleaded guilty to funneling money to Mr. Brown and destroying evidence.

headline.main: Another Former Aide of Mayor Is Accused In Campaign Inquiry

byline.original: By MANNY FERNANDEZ and DANIEL CADIS

snippet: Consulting firms recommended spending $210 million to turn the Astrodome, closed since 2008, into a multipurpose facility, but the cost is likely to dominate the debate about its future....
abstract: Houston is attempting to find a new use for the Astrodome, the country's first domed stadium, which has been in disuse since 2008; consulting firms have recommended spending $210 million to turn it into a multipurpose facility, cost that many in the area deem too high. Photos (M)
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON -- Dust is the only thing that rests on the roughly 65,000 red seats of the Astrodome these days. The bright green AstroTurf would trip up any wide receiver headed out for a pass: it lies not smooth and flat but bunched up in waves, as if the victim of a slow-motion earthquake. Amid the cracked entrance ramps and the faded ticket booth signs, the stadium once called ''the eighth wonder of the world'' has become a different sort of wonder: the biggest vacant building in the fourth-largest city in the country, a nine-acre hollow that officials of Harris County spend up to $3 million annually to maintain and secure, though the last major event there was in early 2008.

headline.main: Houston Tries to Find a Use for Its Fading Astrodome

snippet: President Obama, speaking at the Air Force Academy graduation, described keeping the armed forces strong in the wake of tight budgets and the end of two wars....
abstract: President Obama, addressing graduating cadets of the Air Force Academy, vows to keep the military strong even as he winds down the wars of the last decade and makes significant cuts to Pentagon spending. Photo (M)2
lead_paragraph: COLORADO SPRINGS -- President Obama vowed on Wednesday to keep the military strong even as he winds down the wars of the last decade and takes the budget knife to Pentagon spending in an age of increasing government austerity. Addressing the graduating cadets of the Air Force Academy, Mr. Obama said spending cuts were inevitable for the armed forces but he promised to guard against reductions that would compromise the nation's security. Dismissing talk of national decline, he described an ''American century'' in which the United States would continue to flourish.

headline.main: Military Will Remain Strong With Cuts, Obama Tells Cadets

snippet: Msgr. William J. Lynn said that he had little authority to discipline accused priests, and that power rested mainly with his superiors....
abstract: Monsignor William J Lynn takes the stand in his landmark trial to defend himself against allegations that he failed to prevent priests from abusing children during his tenure as secretary for clergy at the Archdiocese of Philadelphia; testifies that he had little authority to discipline accused priests and that power rested mainly with his superiors. (M)
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA -- Msgr. William J. Lynn took the stand on Wednesday in a landmark trial to defend himself against allegations that he failed to prevent fellow Roman Catholic priests from abusing children during his tenure as secretary for clergy at the Archdiocese of Philadelphia. The most senior Catholic Church official in the United States to be tried on charges related to sexual abuse of children, Monsignor Lynn said that he had little authority to discipline accused priests and that power rested mainly with his superiors.

headline.main: Church Official Testifies At His Philadelphia Trial

byline.original: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE and ABBY GOODNOUGH

snippet: The controversy over whether Elizabeth Warren falsely claimed Native American ancestry has fascinated the news media, but voters seem largely indifferent....
abstract: Polls indicate that controversy surrounding Elizabeth Warren's ethnic heritage and whether she misrepresented herself as a minority has so far not been an important issue for voters in Massachusetts, where she is running for a Senate seat. Photos (M)2
lead_paragraph: SOUTH HADLEY, Mass. -- The controversy surrounding Elizabeth Warren's ethnic heritage and whether she misrepresented herself as a minority in the past may have engulfed her Senate campaign and the news media, but in parts of western Massachusetts, voters seem either mystified by it or unconcerned. Desiree Smelcer, 35, a librarian here, said over lunch at the Egg and I that she had heard the buzz. But Ms. Smelcer, a Democrat who is one-eighth Apache, is more focused on the price of gas.

headline.main: Voters Shrug At Revelations Of Ethnic Claim In Senate Race

snippet: A photograph of a young black boy feeling President Obama’s hair has been on view in the West Wing for years....
abstract: Photo of a young black boy patting Pres Obama's hair, perhaps to see if it feels like his own, symbolizes the importance of Obama's presidency to black Americans; blacks continue to maintain deep support for Obama, even if some criticize his reluctance to discuss race. Photo (M)
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON -- For decades at the White House, photographs of the president at work and at play have hung throughout the West Wing, and each print soon gives way to a more recent shot. But one picture of President Obama remains after three years. In the photo, Mr. Obama looks to be bowing to a sharply dressed 5-year-old black boy, who stands erect beside the Oval Office desk, his arm raised to touch the president's hair -- to see if it feels like his. The image has struck so many White House aides and visitors that by popular demand it stays put while others come and go.

headline.main: When a Boy Found a Familiar Feel in a Pat of the Head of State

snippet: Mark Sullivan said there was not national security breach because agents didn’t have specifics about the president’s Colombia trip....
abstract: Secret Service Director Mark J Sullivan, under intense questioning at Senate hearing, says prostitution scandal that erupted in Colombia does not indicate a systemic problem with sex and alcohol in the service. Photo (M)1
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON -- Under skeptical questioning from senators, the director of the Secret Service insisted on Wednesday that the prostitution scandal that erupted in Colombia last month did not indicate a ''systemic'' problem with sex and alcohol in the service. But for the first time, the acting inspector general of the Department of Homeland Security promised an independent investigation of the episode, which was to begin immediately with interviews of agents dismissed in the scandal.

headline.main: Secret Service Chief Sees No 'Systemic' Problems

snippet: The deal ends years of opposition that might have left BP unable to use $4 billion worth of new processing units being installed at Whiting that will allow it to run Canadian tar sands crude as early as next year....
abstract: BP will spend $400 million to install pollution controls at its giant Whiting, Ind, refinery to allow it to process heavy crude oil from Canada, in a deal with federal and state regulators; move will allow company to process Canadian tar sands crude as early as 2013. (M)
lead_paragraph: BP said Wednesday that it would spend $400 million to install pollution controls at its giant Whiting, Ind., refinery to allow it to process heavy crude oil from Canada, in a deal with federal and state regulators. The consent decree reached with the Justice Department and Environmental Protection Agency also requires BP, based in London, to pay $8 million to resolve prior claims of clean-air violations at the plant, the sixth-largest American refinery. The deal ends years of opposition that might have left BP unable to use $4 billion worth of new processing units being installed at Whiting that will allow it to run Canadian tar sands crude as early as next year. Midwest refiners have looked to bolster their profits by refitting to process plentiful supplies of Canadian heavy oil, which is cheaper and has a higher content of pollutants that cause acid rain, smog and haze. The Natural Resources Defense Council, which opposed BP's crude slate expansion, said the new pollution equipment would cut emissions from the refinery's flare system by 90 percent.

headline.main: Indiana: In Deal, BP Will Install Pollution Controls at Oil Refinery

snippet: Patrick J. Fitzgerald, who oversaw the criminal prosecutions of successive Illinois governors on corruption charges, will resign at the end of June, the Justice Department announced Wednesday....
abstract: Patrick J Fitzgerald, United States attorney for the Northern District of Illinois since 2001, will retire; oversaw the criminal prosecutions of successive Illinois governors on corruption charges as well as of the former Bush administration White House aide I Lewis Libby Jr. Photo (M)
lead_paragraph: Patrick J. Fitzgerald, the United States attorney who oversaw the criminal prosecutions of successive Illinois governors on corruption charges as well as of the former Bush administration White House aide I. Lewis Libby Jr., will resign at the end of June, the Justice Department announced Wednesday. Mr. Fitzgerald, 51, had served as the United States attorney for the Northern District of Illinois since 2001, making him the longest tenured United States attorney for Chicago. He has worked for the Justice Department for 24 years.

headline.main: U.S. Attorney in Chicago to Step Down

byline.original: By TRIP GABRIEL; Michael Barbaro contributed reporting

snippet: Mitt Romney called for poor and disabled students to be able to use federal funds to attend any public, private or online school they choose....
abstract: Mitt Romney shifts his campaign focus to education, calling for poor and disabled students to be able to use federal funds to attend any public, private or online school they choose; characterizes the poor performance of minority students as a major issue of civil rights. Photo (M)/
lead_paragraph: Lamenting that millions of American children receive ''a third world education,'' Mitt Romney on Wednesday called for poor and disabled students to be able to use federal funds to attend any public, private or online school they choose. In an already feverish campaign contest with President Obama that has focused largely on the economy, Mr. Romney, the presumed Republican nominee, turned his attention to the issue of education.

headline.main: Romney Calls Education 'Civil Rights Issue of Our Era' and Urges Shift

snippet: Robert Champion, a drum major, agreed to walk to the back of a bus as band mates beat him — a hazing ritual that led to his death, according to documents released by prosecutors....
abstract: Prosecutors in the federal hazing case against band mates of Robert Champion detail brutal beating rituals that led to his death; at least 15 Florida A & M University students beat Champion with their hands, drum sticks and mallets as he attempted to reach the back of a bus. (M)
lead_paragraph: MIAMI -- Hoping to earn the respect of his band mates, Robert Champion agreed to enter Bus C in an Orlando parking lot one evening last fall and walk to the back in a common but brutal Florida A & M University hazing ritual -- one that cost him his life, according to documents released Wednesday by prosecutors. Hours after performing at the Florida Classic, a football game in Orlando on Nov. 19, Mr. Champion, a drum major, entered the dark bus and was pummeled with hands, drumsticks, bass drum mallets, straps and even an orange cone. At least 15 band members struck and kicked Mr. Champion as he tried to reach the back of the bus. Once he touched the back, the ritual called ''crossing Bus C,'' part of a rule-laden tradition, would be complete.

headline.main: Hazing Ritual Of a Band Is Described In Documents

snippet: The F.B.I. is investigating what caused as many as 300 inmates to riot on Sunday in an outbreak that left a guard dead and 20 people injured....
abstract: Adams County Correctional Center in Natchez, Miss, which houses illegal immigrants convicted of crimes, remains on lockdown after a violent outbreak that ended with the death of a guard and 20 people injured; Federal Bureau of Investigation is is investigating what caused as many as 300 inmates to riot. Photo (M)
lead_paragraph: A private prison for illegal immigrants in Mississippi remained on lockdown Tuesday after a violent outbreak on Sunday that ended with the death of a guard and 20 people injured. The F.B.I. was investigating what caused as many as 300 inmates to riot with broomsticks and other makeshift weapons at the prison, the Adams County Correctional Center, in Natchez.

headline.main: Mississippi Prison on Lockdown After Guard Dies

snippet: While many Mormons are rooting for Mitt Romney, minorities within the community are becoming more assertive....
lead_paragraph: SALT LAKE CITY -- When Marguerite Driessen, a professor here, entered Brigham Young University in the early 1980s, she was the first black person many Mormon students had ever met, and she spent a good bit of her college time debunking stereotypes about African-Americans. Then she converted to Mormonism herself, and went on to spend a good deal of her adult life correcting assumptions about Mormons. So the matchup in this year's presidential election comes as a watershed moment for her, symbolizing the hard-won acceptance of racial and religious minorities.

headline.main: For Black Mormons, a Political Choice Like No Other

snippet: The assault rate on tribal lands is higher than the national average, and reservation residents who report being attacked often confront gaps in medical and legal help....
abstract: Issue of sexual assaults on American Indian women has become one of the major sources of discord in the debate between the Obama administration and the House of Representatives over the reauthorization of the landmark Violence Against Women Act; the rate of sexual assault of American Indian women is more than twice the national average and reservation residents who report being attacked often confront gaps in medical and legal help. Photos (M)
lead_paragraph: EMMONAK, Alaska -- She was 19, a young Alaska Native woman in this icebound fishing village of 800 in the Yukon River delta, when an intruder broke into her home and raped her. The man left. Shaking, the woman called the tribal police, a force of three. It was late at night. No one answered. She left a message on the department's voice mail system. Her call was never returned. She was left to recover on her own. ''I drank a lot,'' she said this spring, three years later. ''You get to a certain point, it hits a wall.''

headline.main: For Native American Women, Scourge of Rape, Rare Justice

snippet: The Department of Defense recently confirmed the deaths of the following Americans....
abstract: Defense Department confirms the deaths of three American service members in Afghanistan. (S)5
lead_paragraph: The Department of Defense has identified 1,964 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently: ALEXANDER, Tobias C., 30, Second Lt., Army; Lawton, Okla.; 168th Brigade Support Battalion, 214th Fires Brigade.

headline.main: Names of the Dead

snippet: With Ron Paul having lost the nomination, his dedicated supporters are swarming lightly guarded Republican redoubts in an attempt to infiltrate the top echelons of the party....
abstract: Rep Ron Paul's dedicated supporters are setting their sights down-ballot in an attempt to infiltrate the top echelons of the Republican Party, now that Paul has lost the 2012 presidential nomination; Republican Party officials say they are in daily contact with Paul, in a delicate effort to harness the energy around him without inciting his supporters. Photos (M)
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON -- Armed with an inherited fortune and a devotion to Ron Paul, John Ramsey, a 21-year-old college student from Nacogdoches, Tex., plunged into a little-watched Republican House primary in Northern Kentucky this spring to promote his version of freedom. More than $560,000 later, Mr. Ramsey's chosen standard-bearer, Thomas H. Massie, a Republican, cruised to victory Tuesday in the race to select a successor to Representative Geoff Davis, a Republican who is retiring.

headline.main: After Paul Falters, Backers Push Agenda in Party and Other Races

snippet: The judges said that the deal Congress approved in 2010, over land trust royalties mismanaged by the Interior Department, was fair and was the best that could be hoped for without more years of litigation....
abstract: Three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals dismisses a challenge to the $3.4 billion settlement between the federal government and hundreds of thousands of Native Americans whose land trust royalties were mismanaged by the Interior Department. (M)
lead_paragraph: A three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit has dismissed a challenge to a $3.4 billion settlement between the federal government and hundreds of thousands of Native Americans whose land trust royalties were mismanaged by the Interior Department. The judges said Tuesday that the deal Congress approved in 2010 was fair and was the best that could be hoped for without more years of litigation. Kimberly Craven of Boulder, Colo., had objected to the settlement, saying that it did not account for how much money was lost and that some beneficiaries would be overcompensated. The deal is the result of a class-action lawsuit filed in 1996.

headline.main: Judges Dismiss Challenge To a Deal With Native Americans

snippet: President Obama and Mitt Romney are making starkly different appeals that reflect the divergent ideologies and core constituencies of the two parties....
abstract: Political memo; Pres Obama and presumptive Republican presidential nominee Mitt Romney are making starkly different appeals that reflect the divergent ideologies and core constituencies of the two parties; Obama champions the government as a linchpin of economic growth and protector of Americans, while Romney condemns government as a menace that imperils the free market's ability to enhance individual opportunity and make the nation prosperous. Photos (M)
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON -- The currency of political persuasion is emotion -- and the way President Obama and Mitt Romney are spending it crystallizes their starkly contrasting appeals. An Obama campaign video shows the president's national political director, Katherine Archuleta, tearfully crediting Mr. Obama with having saved her daughter's life. She portrays the president as a hero of government whose health care law assures her daughter, a cancer survivor, insurance coverage forever.

headline.main: In One Corner, a Champion of Government. In the Other, Its Foe.

snippet: Rev. Alvaro Corcuera sent a letter to his members on Tuesday admitting that he had known since 2005 that his most prominent American priest, the Rev. Thomas Williams, had fathered a child....
abstract: Legionaries of Christ head Rev Alvaro Corcuera sends a letter to his members admitting that he had known since 2005 that Rev Thomas Williams, his most prominent American priest, had fathered a child. (S)t
lead_paragraph: The head of the Legionaries of Christ, a Roman Catholic religious order, sent a letter to his members on Tuesday admitting that he had known since 2005 that his most prominent American priest, the Rev. Thomas Williams, had fathered a child. The Associated Press reported that the Rev. Alvaro Corcuera, the order's superior in Rome, said he regretted allowing Father Williams to continue giving public lectures and television interviews on living a moral life and teaching moral theology to seminarians. The Legion is trying to recover from revelations that its founder sexually abused seminarians and fathered several children. Father Williams, whose affair became public last week, sent an e-mail to Legion members on Tuesday, apologizing for failing to heed his superior's advice to keep a lower profile.

headline.main: Leader Of Catholic Order Admits Knowing Priest Fathered Child

snippet: While waiting for a verdict in federal corruption trial of former Senator John Edwards, the press corps has taken in minor league baseball and civil rights history....
abstract: Reporter's Notebook; reporters covering the federal corruption trial of former Sen John Edwards in Greensboro, NC, are exploring the city while the jury deliberates on its verdict. Photo (M)a
lead_paragraph: GREENSBORO, N.C. -- Like flags on an Army base, the microwave dishes on the news trucks that ring the federal courthouse here rise around 6 a.m. And then the waiting begins.

headline.main: Waiting for an Edwards Verdict, and Getting Acquainted With Greensboro

lead_paragraph: A passenger of the US Airways plane scheduled to fly from Paris to Charlotte, N.C., told the crew that she had a surgically implanted device, the authorities said.

snippet: A report released by an immigration group was broadly critical of the American immigration system, which it said is slow, inflexible and not synchronized with the nation’s labor needs....
abstract: Partnership for a New American Economy report says the United States is facing intense competition from foreign countries, especially China, that are seeking to persuade highly skilled citizens who have settled in the US to return home to start businesses; the report contends the US immigration system is slow, inflexible and not synchronized with the nation's labor needs. (M)
lead_paragraph: The United States is facing intense competition from foreign countries, especially China, that are seeking to persuade highly skilled citizens who have settled in this country to return home to start businesses there, according to a report released Tuesday by an immigration group led by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg of New York. ''China is proving the most aggressive and ambitious'' among the United States' economic competitors in seeking to reverse a brain drain and lure back their scientists, engineers and entrepreneurs, the report by Mr. Bloomberg's group, the Partnership for a New American Economy, found.

headline.main: U.S. Sees Other Countries Luring Expatriates to Return

snippet: Kathleen Sebelius, the secretary of health and human services, called Ms. Beckett “an inadvertent pioneer in the civil rights movement for people with disabilities.”...
abstract: Katie Beckett, who became an inadvertent pioneer in the civil rights movement for people with disabilities and the inspiration for regulations that have allowed more than 500,000 disabled children to live at home since 1981, dies at age 34. Photos (M).
lead_paragraph: Katie Beckett, who was 3 years old and had been hospitalized almost since birth when President Ronald Reagan invoked her case as an example of irrational federal regulation in 1981 -- a crucial moment in the movement toward government support for home health care -- died on Friday in Cedar Rapids, Iowa, in the hospital where she was born. She was 34, more than three times the age her doctors had predicted she would reach. The cause was a digestive disorder not related to the brain inflammation that led to her lifelong respiratory difficulties, her mother, Julie Beckett, said.

headline.main: Katie Beckett, 34; Inspired Shift on Care

snippet: A federal investigation of Mayor Vincent C. Gray’s 2010 election campaign has roared back into the public eye....
abstract: Federal investigation of Washington, DC, Mayor Vincent C Gray's 2010 election campaign returns to the public eye as Thomas W Gore, a former campaign fund-raiser for Gray, pleads guilty in a plea deal to obstruction of justice and violations of the city's campaign finance laws. Photo (M)
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON -- For more than a year, a federal inquiry of Mayor Vincent C. Gray's 2010 election campaign has smoldered in the nation's capital. After raids and subpoenas, intrigue flared and receded. Through it all, rumors swirled around the secret work of a grand jury. On Tuesday, the investigation roared back into the public eye when Thomas W. Gore, a former campaign fund-raiser for Mr. Gray, pleaded guilty in a plea deal to obstruction of justice and violations of the city's campaign finance laws. The charges are the first in the investigation of Mr. Gray's campaign, but many in the city predict more to come.

headline.main: With Ex-Aide's Plea Deal, Clouds for Washington Mayor

snippet: The Emmonak Women’s Shelter in Alaska, uniquely situated in a Native American village, needs more money to survive beyond this summer....
abstract: Emmonak Women's Shelter in Alaska is the state's only center for abused women situated in an Alaska Native village, but will most likely be closed due to the state's elimination of financing for rural services for Alaska Natives in 2005. Map (M)d
lead_paragraph: EMMONAK, Alaska -- There are no roads that lead to this tiny fishing village 500 miles west of Anchorage, no doctor and a single state trooper, who is also responsible for patrolling a dozen other far-flung Yup'ik Eskimo hamlets along the coast of the Bering Sea. The nearest village, Alakanuk, is eight miles away. For a woman who has been sexually assaulted, options for help or escape are limited.

headline.main: In Remote Alaska, Financing Puts a Rare Refuge at Risk

snippet: The new health care law has improved the system for patients, and those gains will survive any Supreme Court decision, some Democratic officials said....
abstract: Democratic officials say the new health care law is already transforming the way care is delivered, and the changes will continue regardless of how the Supreme Court rules on the mandate for most Americans to carry health insurance. (M)1
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON -- The new health care law is already transforming the way care is delivered, and the changes will continue regardless of how the Supreme Court rules on the mandate for most Americans to carry health insurance, a Democratic senator and an Obama administration official said Tuesday. The comments by the senator, Sheldon Whitehouse of Rhode Island, and the official, Dr. Richard J. Gilfillan, director of the federal Center for Medicare and Medicaid Innovation, indicated how Democrats were preparing for a Supreme Court ruling on the 2010 law. The law, which President Obama pushed through Congress on a party-line vote, promises to be a salient issue in elections for the White House and Congress this year.

headline.main: Gains in Health System Seen as Lasting by Some

snippet: The Air Force is taking new action against a former commander of the mortuary at Dover Air Force Base in Delaware and the man who was his top civilian deputy....
abstract: United States Air Force is taking new action against Col Robert H Edmondson, a former commander of the mortuary at Dover Air Force Base in Delaware, and Trevor Dean, his top civilian deputy, for mishandling war remains. (S)a
lead_paragraph: The Air Force is taking new action against a former commander of the mortuary at Dover Air Force Base in Delaware and the man who was his top civilian deputy. The actions announced Monday are to be the final steps in a process that began when the Air Force revealed in November that some war remains had been mishandled at Dover. Col. Robert H. Edmondson has been reprimanded and fined $7,000 for retaliating against workers who blew the whistle on mismanagement. Colonel Edmondson's former civilian deputy, Trevor Dean, was suspended for 20 days without pay. Last year, Colonel Edmondson was reprimanded and denied further command assignments.

headline.main: New Penalties In Military Mortuary Scandal

snippet: A passenger on the US Airways plane en route from Paris to Charlotte, N.C., told the crew that she had a surgically implanted device, the authorities said....
abstract: US Airways flight to Charlotte, NC, from Paris is diverted to Bangor, Me, because of security concerns set off when a passenger tells the crew she has a surgically implanted device; woman is arrested and there is no indication that a bomb is involved in the case. (M)
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON -- A passenger flight to Charlotte, N.C., from Paris was diverted on Tuesday to Bangor, Me., because of security concerns set off when a passenger told the crew that she had a surgically implanted device. Airline and government officials said US Airways Flight 787, carrying 179 passengers and a crew of 9, was escorted safely to land by military aircraft, the standard precaution when a flight is diverted when a flight crew becomes suspicious of a passenger's behavior.

headline.main: Implant Claim Leads Officials To Divert Plane

snippet: Senator Orrin G. Hatch, who led a one-man conservative uprising in Utah in 1976, is the latest Republican veteran hoping to fend off a primary challenger....
abstract: Sen Orrin G Hatch is facing a challenge in Utah's Republican primary from Dan Liljenquist, who is using the same strategy Hatch used in his insurgent primary campaign in 1976; the race is raising profound questions about whether Hatch is still the man that Republican Utahns have loved long and well, or whether he was right in his 1976 campaign when he urged voters to cast out politicians who have hung on too long. Photos (M)a
lead_paragraph: SALT LAKE CITY -- A conservative firebrand identifying himself as a nonpolitician denounces the economic and moral decay of a liberal agenda run amok in Washington, and urges voters to boot out a crusty incumbent who has fallen in love with his own reflection. Sounds like Tea Party 101, right? Now overlay that image with plaid leisure suits and shaggy sideburns, and a different firebrand emerges in a much different time: Senator Orrin G. Hatch.

headline.main: Leader of '76 Insurgency Is Now a Target of One

snippet: Alabama’s only women’s prison is the site of sexual assault and “pervasive sexual harassment,” says a report to be released Tuesday by The Equal Justice Initiative, a nonprofit group....
abstract: Nonprofit group The Equal Justice Initiative releases report saying that the Julia Tutwiler Prison for Women, Alabama's only women's prison, is the site of sexual assault and harassment. (S)
lead_paragraph: The Julia Tutwiler Prison for Women, Alabama's only women's prison, is the site of sexual assault and ''pervasive sexual harassment,'' says a report to be released Tuesday by The Equal Justice Initiative, a nonprofit group based in Montgomery. The report says guards have impregnated at least two inmates; it describes other instances of sexual assaults by guards, in one case by a chaplain. The report also says inmates are punished for reporting sexual misconduct.

headline.main: Alabama: Sexual Assaults Reported In Women's Prison

snippet: The census missed more than 1.5 million minority members and overcounted the total population by 36,000 people, according to an assessment released by the Census Bureau on Tuesday....
abstract: Census Bureau says the 2010 census missed more than 1.5 million minority members and overcounted the total population by 36,000 people, or 0.01 percent, but it was mostly accurate. (S)
lead_paragraph: The 2010 census missed more than 1.5 million minority members after struggling to count black Americans, Hispanics, renters and young men, but it was mostly accurate, according to an assessment released by the Census Bureau on Tuesday. Based on a sample survey, the government analysis has been a source of political controversy in the past over whether to adjust census results statistically to correct for undercounts, which usually involve minority members who tend to vote Democratic. The findings show that the 2010 census overcounted the total population by 36,000 people, or 0.01 percent, mostly because of duplicate counts of whites who own multiple homes. That is an improvement from a census overcount of 0.5 percent in 2000. The census missed about 2.1 percent of black Americans and 1.5 percent of Hispanics, accounting for about 1.5 million people. The percentages are statistically comparable to 2000, despite advertising and outreach efforts that pushed census costs to $15 billion.

headline.main: Census Says Its 2010 Count Was Close, but Not Perfect

snippet: Using the story of a struggling family, a Crossroads GPS commercial seeks to appeal to swing voters who had supported President Obama, and may still like him, but are disappointed....
abstract: Super PAC Crossroads GPS debuts political television commercial that seeks to appeal to swing voters who had once supported Pres Obama; ad portrays a financially struggling family, is subtle attempt by Republicans to effectively attack a president who remains well liked even by people who are considering voting against him. Photos (M)2
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON -- The ad is the work of two of the most fearsome players in Republican politics: Larry McCarthy, the producer behind the infamous Willie Horton commercial in 1988, and Crossroads GPS, the political battle squad founded by Karl Rove. When it makes its debut Wednesday in 10 swing states as the centerpiece of a $25 million campaign, it is expected to become one of the most heavily broadcast political commercials of this phase of the general election.

headline.main: Masters of Attack Ads Take Subtle Shot at Obama

snippet: The Department of Defense recently confirmed the deaths of the following Americans....
abstract: Defense Department confirms deaths of two American service members in Afghanistan. (S)4
lead_paragraph: The Department of Defense has identified 1,961 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently: KNAPP, Michael J., 28, Sgt., Army; Overland Park, Kan.; First Battalion, 377th Field Artillery Regiment, 17th Fires Brigade.

headline.main: Names of the Dead

byline.original: By HELENE COOPER and MICHAEL D. SHEAR; Helene Cooper reported from Chicago, and Michael D. Shear from Washington

snippet: President Obama argued the focus of the ad was fair, saying Mitt Romney was making his claim on the presidency based on his experience in private equity....
abstract: Pres Obama defends his campaign's aggressive attacks on Bain Capital, arguing that Mitt Romney's years at the helm of a private equity firm are worthy of a serious debate. Photo (M)
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO -- Responding to criticism from some Democratic supporters, President Obama said Monday that attacks on Mitt Romney's experience at Bain Capital were fair game and that Mr. Romney's years at the helm of a private equity firm were worthy of serious debate. ''This is not a distraction,'' Mr. Obama said about Mr. Romney's record at Bain during a news conference at the end of the NATO summit meeting here. ''This is what this campaign is going to be about.''

headline.main: Facing Criticism, Obama Defends Ads Attacking Romney's Record at Bain Capital

byline.original: By MONICA DAVEY and STEVEN YACCINO

snippet: Chicago was oddly quiet on the final day of the NATO summit meeting, a contrast with the confrontations between the police and protesters on Sunday night....
abstract: Chicago is quiet on final day of the NATO summit meeting, with only a relatively small protest held outside the headquarters of Boeing; ending is subdued one for a city that had, for months, braced for chaos that the global summit might bring. Photo (M)/
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO -- On the final day of the NATO summit meeting here, Chicago was oddly quiet. Several hundred demonstrators, a far smaller group than had marched through downtown in the days before, staged a ''die in'' on Monday outside the headquarters of Boeing, whose workers, like many Chicagoans, had stayed home to avoid trouble. It was a subdued ending for a city that had, for months, braced for chaos that a global summit meeting might bring and had, for ages, bristled at the images from its 1968 Democratic convention, when the police and protesters battled for days.

headline.main: Day of Subdued Protests Follows Night of Clashes in Chicago

byline.original: By NICHOLAS CONFESSORE, JO CRAVEN McGINTY and DEREK WILLIS

snippet: “Super PACs” and issue-advocacy groups supporting Mitt Romney have narrowed President Obama’s once-commanding advantage....
abstract: Pres Obama's once-commanding campaign fund-raising advantage in the 2012 presidential election is declining as major Republican donors, conservative super PACs and tax-exempt issue-advocacy groups raise huge amounts of cash for Mitt Romney. Chart (M)l
lead_paragraph: President Obama's once-commanding fund-raising advantage is declining as major Republican donors rally for Mitt Romney, conservative ''super PACs'' far outpace their liberal counterparts and tax-exempt issue-advocacy groups swarm the political landscape. With Republican Congressional committees largely keeping pace with the Democrats, Mr. Obama and his Democratic allies appear increasingly likely to be matched or even outspent by Republican and conservative groups -- a far cry from 2008, when Mr. Obama outspent Senator John McCain by more than two to one and super PACs did not exist. All told, Mr. Obama, Congressional Democrats and liberal groups have raised at least $547 million in this election cycle while Mr. Romney, Congressional Republicans, and the top conservative outside groups have raised at least $462 million, according to a review of reports filed with the Federal Election Commission through Sunday and interviews with officials.

headline.main: Fund-Raising for Romney Eats Into Obama's Edge

snippet: The two were monsignors found unsuitable for ministry after sexually abusing children in parishes and hospitals since the 1960s....
abstract: Two more Roman Catholic priests from the Archdiocese of Philadelphia, George J Mazotta and Hugh P Campbell, are found to be unsuitable for ministry after sexually abusing children; both men had held a series of positions in parishes and hospitals since the 1960s. Photo (M)
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA -- Two more Roman Catholic priests from the Archdiocese of Philadelphia have been found unsuitable for ministry after sexually abusing children. The archdiocese said Sunday that it had substantiated allegations of sexual abuse of a minor against Msgr. George J. Mazzotta, 73, and Msgr. Hugh P. Campbell, 77, who were ordained in the 1960s and held a series of positions in Philadelphia-area parishes and hospitals.

headline.main: 2 Philadelphia Priests Punished in Sexual Abuse Cases

snippet: The Supreme Court said twins conceived from a dead father’s frozen sperm are not entitled to Social Security survivor benefits if they cannot inherit his property under state law....
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON -- Children conceived with a dead father's frozen sperm are not entitled to Social Security benefits if they were not eligible to inherit property from him under state law, the Supreme Courtruled unanimously on Monday. The case concerned twins born to Karen Capato 18 months after the death of her husband, Robert, in 2002. The Social Security Administration denied the twins survivors' benefits, a determination the Supreme Court endorsed.

headline.main: Children Not Entitled to Dead Father's Benefits, Justices Rule

snippet: Forty-three groups are challenging the Obama administration’s rule that employees receive health insurance coverage for contraception....
abstract: Forty-three Roman Catholic groups file lawsuits in 12 federal courts to challenge the Obama administration rule requiring that employees receive coverage for contraception in their health insurance policies; suit claims that mandate is an unprecedented attack on their religious beliefs. (M)
lead_paragraph: In an effort to show a unified front in their campaign against the birth control mandate, 43 Roman Catholic dioceses, schools, social service agencies and other institutions filed lawsuits in 12 federal courts on Monday, challenging the Obama administration's rule that their employees receive coverage for contraception in their health insurance policies. The nation's Catholic bishops, unable to reverse the ruling by prevailing on the White House or Congress, have now turned to the courts, as they warned they would. The bishops say the requirement is an unprecedented attack on religious liberty because it compels Catholic employers to provide access to services that are contrary to their religious beliefs. The mandate is part of the Obama administration's overhaul of the health care system, which the bishops say they otherwise support.

headline.main: Bishops Sue Over Contraception Mandate

keywords.name: subject

snippet: Facing opposition to a new studio in Lucas Valley, George Lucas said he would bring low-income housing there instead, inflaming wealthy neighbors in Marin County....
abstract: George Lucas, after facing community opposition to his bid to expand his digital studio in Lucas Valley, announces that he will instead sell the land to a developer to build low-income housing; news inflames his wealthy neighbors in Marin County, Calif. Map, Photos (M)
lead_paragraph: SAN RAFAEL, Calif. -- In 1978, a year after ''Star Wars'' was released, George Lucas began building his movie production company far from Hollywood, in the quiet hills and valley of Marin County here just north of San Francisco. Starting with Skywalker Ranch, the various pieces of Lucasfilm came together over the decades behind the large trees on his 6,100-acre property, invisible from the single two-lane road that snakes through the area. And even as his fame grew, Mr. Lucas earned his neighbors' respect through his discretion. Marin, one of America's richest counties, liked it that way.

headline.main: Lucas and Rich Neighbors Agree to Disagree: Part II

snippet: The Supreme Court will decide whether a challenge to a 2008 federal law that broadened the government’s power to monitor international communications may proceed....
abstract: Supreme Court agrees to hear case challenging a 2008 federal law that broadened the government's power to monitor international communications; court also issues decision denying Social Security benefits to children conceived using their dead father's sperm; also decides that length of immigrant parents' lawful residence in the US should not be considered in determining whether their children may be deported; finally, rules that federal law requiring lawsuit winners to pay for interpreters does not cover cost of translating documents. Photo (M)
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON -- The Supreme Court on Monday agreed to hear a case concerning the government's use of electronic surveillance to monitor the international communications of people suspected of having ties to terrorist groups. The court also issued three decisions, including one denying Social Security benefits to children who were conceived through artificial insemination after their father's death. SURVEILLANCE The justices agreed to decide whether a challenge may proceed to a 2008 federal law that broadened the government's power to monitor international communications. The law, an amendment to the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act, followed disclosure of the Bush administration's secret program to wiretap international communications without obtaining court warrants in the wake of the Sept. 11 attacks.

headline.main: Supreme Court Agrees to Hear Case on Surveillance

snippet: Gregory B. Jaczko, who battled colleagues and Congress as chairman of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, will step down as soon as a successor is confirmed....
abstract: Gregory B Jaczko, whose three-year tenure as chairman of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission has been marked by bitter battles with colleagues and with Congress, announces that he will step down as soon as a successor is confirmed. (M)1
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON -- Gregory B. Jaczko, whose three-year tenure as chairman of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission has been marked by bitter battles with colleagues and with Congress, announced Monday that he would step down as soon as a successor was confirmed. The White House said it would name a successor ''soon,'' but it is unlikely that anyone will be confirmed to succeed Dr. Jaczko for many months, ensuring continued turmoil at the deeply divided agency. The commission's inspector general is preparing a report to be issued in coming weeks that is expected to repeat some of the charges of mismanagement and verbal abuse of subordinates that have isolated Dr. Jaczko from other members.

headline.main: Chairman Of N.R.C. To Resign Under Fire

snippet: An assistant treasurer for the 2010 campaign of the District of Columbia mayor has been charged with making improper donations to another mayoral candidate and destroying evidence related to the contributions....
abstract: Thomas Gore, an assistant treasurer for the 2010 campaign of the District of Columbia Mayor Vincent Gray, is charged with making improper donations to another mayoral candidate and destroying evidence related to the contributions; charges are first to arise from a federal investigation of Gray's campaign. (S)
lead_paragraph: An assistant treasurer for the 2010 campaign of the District of Columbia mayor has been charged with making improper donations to another mayoral candidate and destroying evidence related to the contributions. The charges against the aide, Thomas Gore, are the first to arise from a federal investigation of Mayor Vincent Gray's campaign. They were filed Monday in a criminal information, which indicates a defendant is likely to plead guilty. Records indicate the money went to Sulaimon Brown, who accused Mr. Gray of promising him a job in exchange for negative comments about Adrian Fenty, then the mayor.

headline.main: Campaign Aide Faces Charges Over Donations

snippet: The president spoke to graduates of Joplin High School, which was destroyed, along with nearly a third of the Missouri city, in a tornado a year ago....
abstract: Pres Obama gives commencement speech to graduates of Joplin High School, which was destroyed, along with nearly a third of Joplin, Mo, in a deadly tornado in May 2011; salutes city and its people for their ability to heal and grow after the devastation. Photo (M)
lead_paragraph: JOPLIN, Mo. -- The clock at Joplin High School stopped a year ago at 5:40 p.m. The class of 2011 had just graduated, and students, parents and teachers were heading home when a powerful tornado ripped through town, destroying the school, much of the city and the lives of so many on a day that was supposed to be a celebration. A year later, the small city of Joplin held another celebration, this time as a validation of perseverance in the face of untold adversity. With the help of President Obama as the commencement speaker on Monday night, Joplin made sure the class of 2012 went into the world as a living testament to those lost and affirmation of those left behind.

headline.main: Year After Tornado, Obama Salutes Joplin's Power to Heal and Grow

snippet: The jury in Greensboro that is deciding whether John Edwards violated campaign finance laws will continue deliberations on Tuesday....
abstract: Jury in Greensboro, NC, that is deciding whether former Sen John Edwards violated campaign finance laws when he sought the 2008 Democratic nomination for president will continue deliberations. (S)
lead_paragraph: The jury in Greensboro that is deciding whether John Edwards violated campaign finance laws when he sought the 2008 Democratic nomination for president will continue deliberations on Tuesday. Late Monday, jurors asked for eight exhibits, most of which were e-mails relating to $725,000 given by the heiress Rachel Mellon.

headline.main: North Carolina: Edwards Jurors Continue Talks

byline.original: By STEVEN YACCINO and MONICA DAVEY; Idalmy Carrera contributed reporting

snippet: Protesters and police clashed in the most fractious confrontation yet following a series of weekend protests against the NATO summit meeting being held here....
abstract: Protesters at NATO summit meeting clash with the Chicago police as officers try to disperse thousands of people who gathered several blocks from the site of the meeting and refused to leave; about 45 protesters are arrested, and at least four officers are injured in standoff. Photo (M)a
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO -- Protesters at the NATO summit meeting clashed with the Chicago police late Sunday as officers tried to disperse thousands of people who had gathered several blocks from the site of the meeting and refused demands to leave. The standoff, which lasted several hours, grew intense as police officers, some in riot gear and gas masks, and protesters, some wearing all black, confronted one another, and shoving and scuffles broke out.

headline.main: Police Officers and Protesters Clash in Chicago Outside Meeting of NATO Leaders

byline.original: By RAYMOND HERNANDEZ; Helene Cooper contributed reporting

snippet: Mayor Cory A. Booker of Newark sharply criticized an advertisement about Mitt Romney’s private equity work....
abstract: Newark Mayor Cory A Booker sharply criticizes Pres Obama's campaign for attacking Mitt Romney's work at the private equity firm Bain Capital; argues that one of the campaign's television advertisements unfairly portrayed private equity as a job-killing industry. Photo (M)
lead_paragraph: Mayor Cory A. Booker of Newark, a prominent Democrat enlisted as a surrogate for President Obama's campaign, sharply criticized it on Sunday for attacking Mitt Romney's work at the private equity firm Bain Capital. Mr. Booker, speaking on the NBC program ''Meet the Press,'' made his comments in response to a television advertisement the president's campaign unveiled last week. It portrays Mr. Romney, the presumptive Republican presidential nominee, as someone who eliminated jobs for the sake of profits during his years running Bain Capital.

headline.main: Newark Mayor Criticizes Obama's Ad About Bain
