lead_paragraph: An effort is under way to limit the practice of fast-tracking of regulations by White House administrations that are on their way out.

headline.main: Agency Aims to Curb Rules Issued by Lame-Duck Presidents

byline.original: By ABBY GOODNOUGH; Jess Bidgood and Jen McCaffery contributed reporting

snippet: A video game company owned by Curt Schilling, the former Red Sox pitcher, failed to make a $1.1 million payment on a loan with controversial backing from Rhode Island....
abstract: Video game company 38 Studios, founded by former Boston Red Sox pitcher Curt Schilling, fails to make a $1.1 million payment on a loan with controversial backing from Rhode Island. Photos (M)
lead_paragraph: PROVIDENCE, R.I. -- Curt Schilling is a hero to Boston Red Sox fans who remember him pitching valiantly against the Yankees in the 2004 American League Championship Series with an injured ankle and a bloody sock. But a strange chain of events last week left some Rhode Islanders feeling differently. Mr. Schilling, now retired from baseball, started a video game company that he moved here from Massachusetts after securing a controversial $75 million loan guarantee in 2010 from the economically stressed state. Early last week, Gov. Lincoln Chafee let it be known that Mr. Schilling's company, 38 Studios, had failed to make a required $1.1 million payment to the Rhode Island Economic Development Corporation. The state, he said, was scrambling to help 38 Studios stay solvent.

headline.main: Trouble in Rhode Island For Boston Baseball Hero Trying Out a New Game

snippet: A 54-month sentence given to the already-imprisoned son of the actor Michael Douglas prompted a group to push for more treatment, instead of more prison time....
abstract: Group of prominent addiction doctors is mounting a legal campaign on behalf of Cameron Douglas, troubled son of Michael Douglas who is serving a five-year federal sentence for drug distribution; group is pushing for treatment for already-imprisoned Douglas instead of an additional 54-month sentence tacked on after he was caught behind bars with illegal and prescription drugs. Photo (M)
lead_paragraph: A group of prominent addiction doctors has mounted a quiet legal campaign on behalf of Cameron Douglas, the troubled son of the actor Michael Douglas, in hopes of finding a sympathetic ear for their view that drug addiction is best handled with more treatment, not more prison time. In December, Mr. Douglas, who is 33 and already serving a five-year federal sentence for drug distribution and heroin possession, was sentenced to an additional four and a half years after being caught behind bars with heroin and Suboxone, a prescription medication used to blunt the pull of opioid addiction.

headline.main: New Approach Sought for Jailed Addicts

snippet: The two lives of John Edwards have collided spectacularly in the federal courthouse where the government is trying him on charges of campaign finance fraud and conspiracy....
lead_paragraph: GREENSBORO, N.C. -- John Edwards ran for president in 2008 vowing to bridge the two Americas, the rich one and the poor one. There were two John Edwardses as well: a candidate and a lover so enthralled with his mistress that he could not stop the affair even when his top aides told him it would ruin his political career. Whether the two Americas will ever become one remains to be seen. But the two lives of John Edwards have collided spectacularly in a federal courthouse here, where the government is trying him on six counts of campaign finance fraud and conspiracy.

headline.main: Candidate, Philanderer and Juggler, Too: Edwards Trial Shows Deception's Strains

byline.original: By NICHOLAS CONFESSORE; Jo Craven McGinty and Derek Willis contributed reporting

snippet: The freedom and unlimited cash of outside groups have increased the influence of a growing number of consultants and operatives in both parties....
abstract: Campaigns from the presidential race down to House contests are becoming longer and more intense, driven by deep-pocketed donors eager to see incumbents pummeled throughout the political cycle; decisions about attack ads and negative campaigning that once weighed on candidates are now made by consultants and donors with little or no accountability to the public; as this is the first presidential campaign since the Supreme Court opened the door for super PACs and unlimited campaign spending, it is still unclear how voters will respond. Photos (M)
lead_paragraph: The intensifying flood of uncapped donations to outside political groups is transforming not just campaigns but the entire business of politics. Once seasonal affairs, campaigns from the presidential race down to House contests are becoming longer and more intense, driven by deep-pocketed donors eager to see incumbents pummeled throughout the political cycle. Decisions about attack ads and negative campaigning that once weighed on candidates are now made by consultants and donors with little or no accountability to the public.

headline.main: 'Super PACs' Let Strategists Off the Leash

snippet: An effort is under way to limit the practice of fast-tracking of regulations by White House administrations that are on their way out....
abstract: Administrative Conference of the United States, an independent federal agency, is pushing to curb the ability of lame-duck presidents to enact contentious regulations at the end of their terms; are recommending that Congress be given expanded powers to delay such regulations from taking effect. Photo (M)y
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON -- It is a political tradition that is almost as old as the White House: a president on the way out, unconstrained by electoral considerations, fast-tracks a flurry of contentious regulations in the waning hours of his term, sometimes even cutting short review from industry or the public. As he was leaving, President George W. Bush expanded Justice Department surveillance powers, relaxed rules on certain types of coal mining and altered protections for endangered animals. President Bill Clinton pushed through new rules on chemicals in drinking water and on workplace injuries caused by repetitive movements.

headline.main: Agency Aims to Curb Rules by Lame-Duck Presidents

snippet: Millions of dollars in outside money began pouring into Congressional contests around the country in April, while spending by presidential “super PACs” dropped off....
abstract: Federal Election Commission releases data showing that outside groups have spent at least $7 million on House races and $12.4 million on Senate races since the beginning of April; super PAC spending in the presidential contest has dropped off in the same period. Photo (M)
lead_paragraph: Millions of dollars in outside money began pouring into Congressional contests around the country in April, while spending by presidential ''super PACs'' dropped off, according to records filed with the Federal Election Commission on Sunday and other data. Outside groups, including super PACs and advocacy organizations, have spent at least $7 million on House races and $12.4 million on Senate races since the beginning of April, the first wave in what is expected to be a flood of independent spending this year in the battle for control of Congress.

headline.main: Outside Spending Turns From Presidential Race to Congressional Contests

snippet: For years, cyclists in Los Angeles were a renegade subculture. These days, they are downright mainstream....
abstract: Los Angeles is experiencing a bicycling boom, adding close to 40 miles of bike paths and lanes across the city in 18 months; bicyclists have gone from years of being a renegade subculture to mainstream, and there appears to be a renegotiation of space occurring between drivers and riders as they try to figure out how to share the road. Photos (M)
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES -- It was a warm April morning in downtown Los Angeles, and there was not a car on the road. For five hours, the streets were commandeered by nearly 100,000 people on bicycles -- old and young, wearing spandex and silly hats, dogs and babies perched on handlebar baskets -- in a celebration that produced a sight that once would have seemed inconceivable in this city of cars. It was the fourth time this city closed its streets for the event known as CicLAvia, and it was the largest one yet.

headline.main: Los Angeles Lives by Car, but Learns to Embrace Bikes

snippet: Anyone born from 1945 to 1965 should get a one-time blood test to see if they have the virus, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said in draft recommendations on Friday....
abstract: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention proposes that all baby boomers born from 1945 to 1965 get tested for hepatitis C. (S)
lead_paragraph: The government is proposing that all baby boomers get tested for hepatitis C. Anyone born from 1945 to 1965 should get a one-time blood test to see if they have the liver-destroying virus, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said in draft recommendations on Friday. Baby boomers account for more than 2 million of the 3.2 million Americans infected with the virus. It is most commonly spread now by sharing needles to inject drugs. Before the widespread screening of blood donations began in 1992, it was also spread through transfusions. Health officials believe that hundreds of thousands of infections occurred each year in the 1970s and 1980s, most of them in baby boomers.

headline.main: Proposal Backs Hepatitis C Test For Baby Boomers

snippet: Joplin is getting another big boost from the United Arab Emirates as it rebuilds from a tornado that killed 161 people last year....
abstract: Yousef Al Otaiba, United Emirates ambassador to the United States, announces a $5 million donation to Mercy Hospital in Joplin, Mo, which was one of the 8,000 buildings destroyed in a 2011 tornado. (S)
lead_paragraph: Joplin is getting another big boost from the United Arab Emirates as it rebuilds from a tornado that killed 161 people last year. Ambassador Yousef Al Otaiba was in Joplin on Friday to announce that the United Arab Emirates was donating $5 million to Mercy Hospital for a pediatric section and a neonatal intensive care unit. The hospital was one of the 8,000 buildings destroyed in the May 22, 2011, tornado. In August, the United Arab Emirates announced a challenge grant that could be worth up to $1 million to buy laptop computers for all 2,200 students at Joplin High School, which also was destroyed.

headline.main: Missouri: More Help For Joplin From the Persian Gulf

snippet: Tom Leppert cites his accomplishments as a big-city mayor, while his detractors claim he used local office as a steppingstone....
lead_paragraph: Tom Leppert was a virtual unknown on the Dallas political scene before 2007, when he beat 10 other candidates to become the city's mayor. At the time, he insisted he was focused on the city's problems and not on higher office. While Mr. Leppert was mayor, AT&T moved its headquarters to Dallas, the crime rate dropped and major projects that had been stalled for years moved forward.

headline.main: Leppert Takes Mayoral Record Into Senate Race

byline.original: By JODI KANTOR; Ashley Parker contributed reporting

snippet: While Mitt Romney has said little about his Mormon faith on the campaign trail, people who know him well call it a huge influence on his conduct and worldview....
abstract: People close to Mitt Romney insist that his Mormonism is a driving force in his life, despite fact that he rarely mentions his faith on the campaign trail; Romney's long history with the Mormon church includes missionary work and strict adherence to its laws and dogmas (Series: The Long Run). Photos (L)
lead_paragraph: BELMONT, Mass. -- When Mitt Romney embarked on his first political race in 1994, he also slipped into a humble new role in the Mormon congregation he once led. On Sunday mornings, he stood in the sunlit chapel here teaching Bible classes for adults. Leading students through stories about Jesus and the Nephite and Lamanite tribes, who Mormons believe once populated the Americas, and tossing out peanut butter cups as rewards, Mr. Romney always returned to the same question: how could students apply the lessons of Mormon scripture in their daily lives?

headline.main: Romney's Faith, Silent but Deep

snippet: President Obama concluded in his first year that the Bush-era dream of remaking Afghanistan was a fantasy. The lessons he has learned there have shaped his presidency....
abstract: Pres Obama, attending a NATO summit meeting in Chicago, is expected to announce an end to all combat operations in Afghanistan by the summer of 2013; decision culminates a long evolution of Obama's policy on the war, beginning with his rejection of Bush-era nation-building in favor of more attainable objectives. Photo (M)l
lead_paragraph: It was just one brief exchange about Afghanistan with an aide late in 2009, but it suggests how President Obama's thinking about what he once called ''a war of necessity'' began to radically change less than a year after he took up residency in the White House. Not long before, after a highly contentious debate within a war cabinet that was riddled with leaks, Mr. Obama had reluctantly decided to order a surge of more than 30,000 troops. The aide told Mr. Obama that he believed military leaders had agreed to the tight schedule to begin withdrawing those troops just 18 months later only because they thought they could persuade an inexperienced president to grant more time if they demanded it.

headline.main: Charting Obama's Journey To a Shift on Afghanistan

snippet: Representative J. M. Lozano, a Democrat until two months ago, is trying to build his Republican conservative credentials in his re-election campaign, but some Texans see him as an opportunist....
lead_paragraph: When he gets older, Carlos Lozano may very well boast that even as a newborn he had a prominent role in his father's up-and-coming political career. Or Carlos may choose to distance himself from what could be a strategic, and career-derailing, mistake.

headline.main: Party Switcher Is Trying To Prove He Belongs

snippet: The state’s highest court ruled Friday that same-sex couples could divorce in Maryland even though the state does not yet permit same-sex marriages....
abstract: Maryland Court of Appeals rules that same-sex couples can divorce in the state, even though it does not yet permit same-sex marriages. (S)
lead_paragraph: The state's highest court ruled Friday that same-sex couples could divorce in Maryland even though the state does not yet permit same-sex marriages. The Court of Appeals ruled 7 to 0 that couples legally married in another state could divorce. The case involved two women who were married in California and were denied a divorce in 2010. The ruling may have a limited effect because same-sex marriages, and by extension divorces, will start in the state in January.

headline.main: Maryland: Same-Sex Divorces Are Permitted

snippet: The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit upheld a main provision of the Voting Rights Act on Friday, rejecting an Alabama county’s challenge to the law....
abstract: Federal court of appeals upholds main provision of the Voting Rights Act, rejecting an Alabama county's challenge to law; provision requires state governments with a history of discrimination to obtain federal approval before enacting changes to election procedures. (S)
lead_paragraph: In a 2-to-1 decision, the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit upheld a main provision of the Voting Rights Act on Friday, rejecting an Alabama county's challenge to the landmark civil rights law. The provision requires governments with a history of discrimination to obtain approval from the Justice Department or from a federal court in Washington for changes in election procedures. It applies to all or parts of 16 states. The court said that Congress developed extensive evidence of continuing racial discrimination when it reauthorized the provision six years ago.

headline.main: Court Upholds Voting Rights Act In Alabama Case

snippet: After years of exporting prized dinosaur fossils to some of the world’s best museums, Texas will be getting two huge exhibit halls, in Dallas and Houston....
lead_paragraph: Paleontologists have been lifting fossil bones out of Texas' rock beds since the late 19th century. Now, after years of exporting these bones to some of the world's best museums, the state is getting two huge new paleontology halls of its own, both of which offer a visual feast spanning millions of years. ''There are tens of thousands of Texas fossils in fine old museums around the world,'' said Robert T. Bakker, curator of paleontology at the Houston Museum of Natural Science's new 30,000-square-foot hall. Though the state has many smaller, notable fossil museums, Dr. Bakker said ''it's about time'' Texas has two such impressive spaces to showcase its findings.

headline.main: Texas Gets Prehistoric With Two New Fossil Halls

snippet: The board vote put the weight of the country’s most prominent civil rights group behind a cause that has long divided some quarters of the black community....
abstract: NAACP board votes to endorse same-sex marriage in a largely symbolic move; vote puts the weight of the country's most prominent civil rights group behind a cause that has long divided some quarters of the black community. (M)d
lead_paragraph: The board of the N.A.A.C.P. voted to endorse same-sex marriage on Saturday, putting the weight of the country's most prominent civil rights group behind a cause that has long divided some quarters of the black community. The largely symbolic move, made at the group's meeting in Miami, puts the N.A.A.C.P. in line with President Obama, who endorsed gay marriage a little over a week ago. Given the timing, it is likely to be viewed as both a statement of principle as well as support for the president's position in the middle of a closely contested presidential campaign.

headline.main: In Largely Symbolic Move, N.A.A.C.P. Votes to Endorse Same-Sex Marriage

byline.original: By IDALMY CARRERA and STEVEN YACCINO; Joshua Brustein contributed reporting from New York, and Monica Davey from Chicago. Susan C. Beachy provided research

snippet: Three men were planning to attack the campaign headquarters of President Obama and the house of Mayor Rahm Emanuel, among other targets in Chicago, prosecutors said Saturday....
abstract: Tensions mount in Chicago on the eve of a NATO summit meeting after three men are arrested on charges of planning attacks on Pres Obama's re-election campaign headquarters, the house of Mayor Rahm Emanuel, police stations and downtown financial institutions; Brent Betterly, Brian Jacob Church and Jared Chase face terrorism charges. Photos (M)
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO -- Tensions were increasing here on Saturday, the eve of a NATO summit meeting, after three men were accused of planning attacks on President Obama's re-election campaign headquarters, the house of Mayor Rahm Emanuel, police stations and financial institutions in downtown Chicago, according to prosecutors. The men, who were among thousands of people from out of town who traveled to Chicago for a weekend of NATO-related protests, were charged with criminal acts relating to terrorism, conspiracy to commit terrorism, and possession of explosives. Bond for the three men -- Jared Chase, 27, of Keene, N.H.; Brent Betterly, 24, of Oakland Park, Fla.; and Brian Jacob Church, 22, of Fort Lauderdale, Fla. -- was set at $1.5 million each. The state's attorney, Anita Alvarez, said that this was the first time she knew of that defendants had been charged under the state's antiterrorism statute. She declined to comment on possible federal charges.

headline.main: 3 in Chicago Face Charges Of Terrorism In Protests

snippet: President Obama on Sunday will unveil a package of initiatives that includes a hand-over to NATO for the components of an emerging European missile-defense system built by the United States....
abstract: Pres Obama will unveil a new package of NATO initiatives that includes the alliance purchasing a fleet of surveillance drones, sharing weapons and training facilities, and sustaining nuclear deterrence in Europe; a central element will be the hand-over to NATO of control for the components of an emerging European missile-defense system built by the United States. (M)
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON -- President Obama on Sunday will unveil a new package of NATO initiatives that includes the alliance purchasing a fleet of surveillance drones, sharing weapons and training facilities, and sustaining nuclear deterrence in Europe even as disarmament efforts continue with an often belligerent Russia, according to senior administration officials. Although debate on winding down the Afghan war will dominate the NATO summit meeting in Chicago, Mr. Obama will also disclose agreements designed to guarantee mutual security in an era of global austerity that includes sharply reduced military spending across the alliance.

headline.main: U. S. to Unveil Plans to Bolster NATO Alliance

snippet: Tom DeLay is going to court in Austin to appeal convictions, and he’s not very happy about one of the three judges who will hear his case....
lead_paragraph: Ross Ramsey, the managing editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for the Tribune. Tom DeLay can be hard to like.

headline.main: Bad News for the Democrats' Voldemort: Harry Potter Is Holding the Gavel

snippet: Two young men were arrested on Friday in the fatal shooting of two University of Southern California graduate students near the campus last month....
abstract: Los Angeles police arrest Javier Bolden and Bryant Barnes in the shooting deaths of Ming Qu and Ying Wu, two University of Southern California graduate students from China. (M)
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES (AP) -- The police have arrested two young men in the shooting deaths of two University of Southern California graduate students from China, an attack that shocked a campus that has more international students than any other American university. The two men, Javier Bolden, 19, and Bryan Barnes, 20, were arrested on Friday on suspicion of killing the students during what appeared to be a robbery attempt, said Chief Charlie Beck of the Los Angeles Police Department.

headline.main: 2 Arrested In Killings Of Students

byline.original: By KIM SEVERSON; John Schwartz and Bill Dupre contributed reporting

snippet: After five hours, the jury in the federal corruption trial of John Edwards went home for the weekend Friday, leaving few clues about how their deliberations are proceeding....
abstract: Jury in federal corruption trial of John Edwards goes home for the weekend after five hours, leaving few clues about how their deliberations are proceeding. Photo (M)
lead_paragraph: GREENSBORO, N.C. -- After five hours, the jury in the federal corruption trial of John Edwards went home for the weekend Friday, leaving few clues about how their deliberations are proceeding. The jury went to work by midmorning and asked the judge to assemble office supplies and a short list of exhibits and testimony. Chief among them were personal checks and a handwritten letter from Rachel Mellon, the 101-year-old heiress who provided $725,000 to Mr. Edwards, whom she wanted to help become president.

headline.main: Edwards Jury Retires for the Weekend

snippet: Experts warn that voters would not support deep cuts in entitlement programs unless an increase in taxes is part of the mix....
abstract: Statements from Pres Obama and House Speaker John A Boehner suggest a potential replay of their damaging showdown over the debt ceiling in 2011; experts warn that voters will not support deep cuts in entitlement programs unless an increase in taxes is implemented as well. (M)
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON -- President Obama and Republican leaders in Congress made history of sorts last year when they agreed to a 10-year plan to reduce annual deficits with spending cuts and no tax increases. Mr. Obama vows not to let it happen again. Both he and Speaker John A. Boehner put down their respective markers this week, suggesting a potential replay of their damaging showdown over the debt ceiling last summer. On Tuesday, the speaker reiterated what has become known as the Boehner Rule: House Republicans will not increase the debt ceiling again without spending cuts of a greater amount. Mr. Obama, on Wednesday, told him Congress must pass a ''clean'' debt-limit increase to cover the nation's obligations; there will be no more deficit deals, he said, without higher tax revenues from the wealthiest Americans.

headline.main: As a Debt Battle Looms, Budget Veterans See No Option but to Raise Taxes

snippet: President Obama declined to define same-sex marriage as a constitutionally protected federal right even as he endorsed it in a personal capacity....
lead_paragraph: NEW YORK -- This president of the United States is a man from many worlds. Barack Obama has long cast himself as a transcender of tribes. ''Born and raised between opposing dogmas, between cultures, between voices,'' as the novelist Zadie Smith has written, he seems to take pride in acknowledging the truth in multiple ways of seeing. And so he pursues the liberal goal of widening health care access, but relies on private insurers and frames it as a question of budgets more than justice. He sustains and intensifies George W. Bush's ''war on terror,'' while at the same time refusing to call it a war on terror and speaking more gingerly about America's role in the world.

headline.main: Obama Finds Middle Way on Gay Vows

snippet: In a sworn interview with a prosecutor, a girl who was speaking on the phone with Trayvon Martin before he was killed tells of Mr. Martin’s growing fear as he was followed....
abstract: Sworn interview of 16-year-old girl who was on the phone with Trayvon Martin before he was killed describes Martin's growing fear about being followed by George Zimmerman; interview is released along with several dozen others that are submitted as evidence in trial against George Zimmerman, who is charged with second-degree murder. (M)
lead_paragraph: A girl who talked on the phone with Trayvon Martin on the night of Feb. 26 has told a state prosecutor that she heard rising fear in Mr. Martin's voice that peaked with words like ''get off, get off,'' right before she lost contact with him and he was shot to death. In the sworn interview recorded on April 2, which runs more than 22 minutes, the unidentified 16-year-old said Mr. Martin described a man who was ''crazy and creepy'' and on the phone, watching him from a vehicle before he started to follow him on foot.

headline.main: Martin Spoke of 'Crazy and Creepy' Man Following Him, Friend Says

snippet: Even Arthur Miller himself changed his view of his character’s religion and ethnicity over the years....
abstract: Samuel G Freedman On Religion column discusses Arthur Miller play Death of a Salesman; examines enduring and penetrating question of whether Willy Loman, the play's main character, is Jewish. Photo (M)
lead_paragraph: A Yiddish play with the title ''Toyt fun a Salesman'' opened at the Parkway Theater in Brooklyn early in 1951. As most of the audience recognized from the name alone, the show was a translation of Arthur Miller's drama ''Death of a Salesman.'' It seemed a mere footnote to the premiere production, which had completed its triumphal run on Broadway several months earlier, having won the Pulitzer Prize. Even so, a theater critic in Commentary magazine, George Ross, declared of the Brooklyn version, ''What one feels most strikingly is that this Yiddish play is really the original, and the Broadway production was merely Arthur Miller's translation into English.''

headline.main: Since the Opening Curtain, a Question: Is Willy Loman Jewish?

byline.original: By MONICA DAVEY and STEVEN YACCINO

snippet: The demonstration is the first major rally in what is expected to be a weekend of protests as President Obama and foreign leaders gather in the city for a NATO summit meeting....
abstract: Several thousand demonstrators fill a plaza in downtown Chicago for first major rally in what is expected to be a weekend of protests as Pres Obama and foreign leaders gather there for NATO summit meeting. Photos (M)
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO -- Several thousand demonstrators, many of them nurses, filled a plaza in the heart of downtown Chicago on Friday for the first major rally in what is expected to be a weekend of protests as President Obama and foreign leaders gather in the president's hometown for a NATO summit meeting. In a plaza named for former Mayor Richard J. Daley, members of the National Nurses United union, wearing green felt caps, called for a ''Robin Hood tax'' on Wall Street. Some demonstrators later marched through the streets of downtown, at times deflecting police efforts to stop them but eventually scattering as scores of police officers, some in riot helmets, arrived in a pack of unmarked white vans and blocked off access to the Michigan Avenue Bridge over the Chicago River.

headline.main: Chicago Protests Draw Thousands Before NATO Event

snippet: After oral arguments on Friday, it remained unclear how a Virginia court would rule in the case involving James Risen, a New York Times reporter who has refused to reveal his sources....
abstract: Nearly a hour of oral arguments in United States Court of Appeals in Richmond, Va, concludes with no definitive answer as to how the court will rule in case involving James Risen, New York Times reporter who has refused to reveal his sources. (M)/
lead_paragraph: RICHMOND, Va. -- At least two members of a three-judge federal appeals court panel appeared to express some skepticism on Friday about prosecutors' request that they overturn a district judge's order protecting a journalist from being forced to identify his confidential sources in the trial of a former Central Intelligence Agency officer. Nearly an hour of oral arguments here before the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit concluded with no definitive answer as to how the court will rule about whether the journalist, James Risen, can be forced to testify in a high-profile leak case that has raised a significant test of the First Amendment.

headline.main: Appeals Panel Weighs Question on Press Rights

snippet: The legislature failed to heed a call to soften the state’s immigration enforcement law, considered the strictest and most sweeping in the country....
abstract: Alabama Gov Robert Bentley signs into law an immigration enforcement bill only one day after urging the Legislature to make changes to it; law is considered the strictes and most sweeping in the country. (M)6
lead_paragraph: Only a day after calling a special session and urging the Alabama Legislature to make more changes to the state's immigration enforcement law than the modest ones they had passed, Gov. Robert Bentley on Friday signed the bill into law anyway. The governor's decision was arguably the quickest of several reversals that have taken place in recent weeks as politicians in Montgomery, the capital, debated the need for changes to Alabama's immigration enforcement law, considered the strictest and most sweeping in the country.

headline.main: Alabama Gets Strict Immigration Law as Governor Relents

snippet: A Republican political strategist’s leaked proposal for an attack ad suggests that questions about President Obama’s race and religion are still contentious....
abstract: Political Memo; leaked proposal for Republican strategist's attack ad focusing on Pres Obama's former pastor Rev Jeremiah A Wright Jr suggests that questions about Obama's race and religion are still contentious. Photo (M)
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON -- Perhaps the uglier side of politics is always close to the surface. President Obama and his Republican rival, Mitt Romney, have said for months that the 2012 election will be about the economy. But on Thursday, it became -- at least for a brief moment -- about the always touchy issues of race and religion.

headline.main: Race and Religion Rear Their Heads

snippet: Refugees from Africa and South Asia are rebuilding their livelihoods after last summer’s devastating flood that ruined 10,000 acres of land....
abstract: Burlington Journal; refugees from Africa and South Asia who have settled in Vermont are busy re-establishing fields that were damaged by Tropical Storm Irene in 2011, which ruined an estimated 10,000 acres of farmland throughout the state; devastation reminded many of the refugees of the loss and disappointment they fled from, but the act of replanting their fields offers them a sense of belonging and of hope. Photos (M)
lead_paragraph: BURLINGTON, Vt. -- Unpredictability has been a life companion for Clothilde Ntahomvukiye and her fellow refugee farmers from Burundi, who were out clearing stubborn hillocks of weeds and dandelions with hand hoes the other day in a spring drizzle. So last August, when the ferocious torrents of the Winooski River unleashed by Tropical Storm Irene destroyed the farmers' kidney beans, maize and other crops on the cusp of the harvest, the sense of loss and disappointment was at once bewildering and familiar.

headline.main: Refugee Farmers Find Solace in a Floodplain

snippet: The House beat back an unusual coalition of liberal and conservative lawmakers and approved a contentious $642 billion Pentagon policy bill....
abstract: House of Representatives votes down legislation to reject explicitly the indefinite detention of terrorism suspects apprehended on United States soil; House also approves broad military policy bill that will break Pentagon spending caps agreed to in 2011. (M)0
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON -- The House on Friday turned back an unusual coalition of liberals and conservatives and voted down legislation to reject explicitly the indefinite detention of terrorism suspects apprehended on United States soil. House lawmakers then approved a broad military policy bill that would break Pentagon spending caps agreed to just last summer.

headline.main: House Rejects an Effort to Limit Indefinite Detentions

snippet: At a time of fiscal austerity, critics are pointing to the cost of a helicopter part made by a company whose owners are donors to Representative Harold Rogers, a Kentucky Republican....
abstract: Army has bought about $5.6 million worth of $17,000 'leakproof' drip pans from Kentucky company Phoenix Products, foregoing competing product that costs only $2,500; company gained contract after Kentucky Rep Harold Rogers added an earmark to a 2009 spending bill; contract testifies to the enduring power of earmarks, despite several efforts in Congress to rein them in. Diagram, Photos (M)
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON -- In the 1980s, the military had its infamous $800 toilet seat. Today, it has a $17,000 drip pan. Thanks to a powerful Kentucky congressman who has steered tens of millions of federal dollars to his district, the Army has bought about $6.5 million worth of the ''leakproof'' drip pans in the last three years to catch transmission fluid on Black Hawk helicopters. And it might want more from the Kentucky company that makes the pans, even though a similar pan from another company costs a small fraction of the price: about $2,500.

headline.main: Earmark Puts $17,000 Pans On Army Craft

byline.original: By MICHAEL BARBARO and MICHAEL D. SHEAR; Michael Barbaro reported from Hillsborough, N.H., and Michael D. Shear from Washington

snippet: President Obama may have won New Hampshire in 2008, but the people behind Mitt Romney’s campaign believe their candidate’s chances are good this year....
abstract: Mitt Romney's Republican presidential campaign and its supporters view New Hampshire as a real opportunity to pry four electoral votes away from Pres Obama, who won the state decisively in 2008. Photo (M)
lead_paragraph: HILLSBOROUGH, N.H. -- In the days and weeks after the 2008 election, it seemed as if President Obama had permanently yanked independent-minded New Hampshire out of the reach of Republicans. But much has changed since he triumphantly won here four years ago. Republicans surged back to power in the State Capitol in 2010, and Mitt Romney's campaign now views the Granite State as a real opportunity to pry four electoral votes away from Mr. Obama in November.

headline.main: Romney Supporters Hopeful About New Hampshire

snippet: Mr. Ray was hailed as a hero in 1976 for leading 26 children to safety after they were all kidnapped and buried below ground in a truck trailer....
abstract: Ed Ray, the California school bus driver who was hailed as a hero in 1976 for leading 26 children to safety after they were kidnapped and buried below ground in a truck trailer, dies at age 91. Photos (M)
lead_paragraph: Ed Ray, the California school bus driver who was hailed as a hero in 1976 for leading 26 children to safety after they were kidnapped and buried below ground in a truck trailer, died on Thursday at a nursing home in Chowchilla, Calif. He was 91. His death was confirmed by his granddaughter Susan Ray.

headline.main: Ed Ray, 91, Bus Driver During Kidnapping

snippet: Mr. Katzenbach, an attorney general in the Johnson administration, tackled segregation, the Cuban missile crisis, Vietnam War strategy and the Kennedy assassination in his government service....
abstract: Nicholas deB Katzenbach, an attorney general in the Johnson administration who helped shape the political history of the 1960s, dies at age 90. Photos (L)
lead_paragraph: Nicholas deB. Katzenbach, who helped shape the political history of the 1960s, facing down segregationists, riding herd on historic civil rights legislation and helping to map Vietnam War strategy as a central player in both the Kennedy and Johnson administrations, died Tuesday night at his home in Skillman, N.J. He was 90. His death was confirmed by his wife, Lydia.

headline.main: Nicholas Katzenbach, 90, Dies; Policy Maker at '60s Turning Points

snippet: A new form asks voters abroad to say whether they plan to return to the United States. But expatriate groups say this forces people into a choice they don’t want or aren’t able to make....
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON -- The Pentagon office with responsibilities for assisting U.S. military and civilian overseas voters is issuing a new ballot-request form that requires civilian voters to make an all-or-none declaration either that they plan to return to the United States or have no intent of ever doing so. Expatriate groups say the choice is confusing and unfair, carries potential tax ramifications and could depress voting in ways that might affect close elections in November.

headline.main: Change to Ballot Request Form Angers U.S. Expats

snippet: The agency gives Congess more time to act and says it will offer early retirement incentives to tens of thousands of employees....
abstract: United States Postal Service announces that it will keep hundreds of small post offices open by reducing business hours or offering stamps and packaging in grocery stores; new plan whittles down ambitious overhaul that would have closed thousands of offices. Photos (M)l
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON -- The United States Postal Service said Wednesday that it would keep hundreds of small post offices open by reducing business hours or offering stamps and packaging in grocery stores, whittling down its ambitious plan to streamline its services and balance its books by closing thousands of post offices. Giving Congress more time to pass legislation to overhaul the financially struggling agency, the service held back from the wholesale closings of mostly rural post offices that it had proposed last year. The Postal Service's hope is that Congress, given more time, will come up with a plan to overhaul the agency. But Wednesday's action signals that the Postal Service needs to move forward with staffing cuts.

headline.main: Postal Service Alters Plan to Cut Costs

snippet: Legislation passed by the Senate missed the midnight deadline for a hearing in the House....
abstract: Colorado Gov John W Hickenlooper calls for a special legislative session to revive a bill that would have allowed civil unions for same-sex couples in the state; bill's supporters have accused state's Republican legislative leadership of stalling on other unrelated matters, causing debate on the bill to pass a deadline. Photo (M)
lead_paragraph: DENVER -- A call for a special legislative session by Gov. John W. Hickenlooper could revive a bill that would have allowed civil unions for same-sex couples in Colorado. The bill died late Tuesday night after lawmakers reached an impasse over whether it would be heard on the floor of the House of Representatives before the legislative session concluded on Wednesday. The apparent end to the civil unions bill that night was a blow to its supporters, who appeared to have mustered enough votes, including those of several Republicans, to pass it. The bill, which had already passed the State Senate, needed to be heard on the House floor before midnight. Mr. Hickenlooper, a Democrat, had said he intended to sign it.

headline.main: Call for Legislature to Revive Colorado's Civil Union Bill

snippet: Democrats in Wisconsin have a month to persuade voters to unseat the governor, Scott Walker, in a recall election with Tom Barrett as Mr. Walker’s opponent....
abstract: Milwaukee Mayor Tom Barrett wins a Wisconsin Democratic primary and will face Gov Scott Walker in the recall election in June; Walker, who easily won his own primary contest, expresses confidence about the challenge from the Democrats. Photo (M)0
lead_paragraph: MILWAUKEE -- Wisconsin Democrats will get a do-over election between Gov. Scott Walker and Tom Barrett when the two face off in a rare recall vote next month. Mr. Barrett, the mayor of Milwaukee, got the nod from his party after a statewide primary on Tuesday, beating a fellow Democrat, Kathleen Falk, a former Dane County executive who had been seen by some as labor's preferred candidate.

headline.main: Wisconsin Democrats Choose Challenger to Run Against Governor in Recall Race

snippet: Obama administration officials say a new timetable developed by the Army Corps of Engineers should speed up the search for a permanent way to protect the Great Lakes from Asian carp and other invasive species....
abstract: Obama administration officials say a new timetable developed by the Army Corps of Engineers should speed up the search for a permanent way to protect the Great Lakes from Asian carp and other invasive species. (M)l
lead_paragraph: Obama administration officials say a new timetable developed by the Army Corps of Engineers should speed up the search for a permanent way to protect the Great Lakes from Asian carp and other invasive species. Officials said Tuesday that the corps will present a shortlist of options by the end of 2013 for preventing the carp and other fish from migrating between the Great Lakes and Mississippi River basins through waterways in the Chicago area. Congress will have the authority to make a final choice. Members of Congress and state officials said the corps' previous plan to develop a single recommendation by late 2015 was not fast enough.

headline.main: Corps Of Engineers To Devise Faster Plan To Protect Lakes From Invasive Species

byline.original: By MONICA DAVEY; Carl Hulse and Jennifer Steinhauer contributed reporting from Washington

snippet: Richard G. Lugar, one of the Senate’s longest-serving members, lost a hard-fought Republican primary to Richard E. Mourdock, the Indiana state treasurer....
abstract: Indiana's six-term Sen Richard G Lugar, one of the Senate's longest-serving members, loses a hard-fought Republican primary to Richard E Mourdock, the state treasurer; Mourdock's campaign was fueled by Tea Party groups and national conservative organizations that deemed collegial moderate Lugar too willing to compromise. Photos, Chart (M)0
lead_paragraph: INDIANAPOLIS -- Richard G. Lugar, one of the Senate's longest-serving members, a collegial moderate who personified a gentler political era, was turned out of office on Tuesday, ending a career that had spanned the terms of half a dozen presidents. Mr. Lugar, a six-term senator from Indiana who had won most of his recent elections with more than 60 percent of the vote, lost a hard-fought Republican primary to Richard E. Mourdock, the state treasurer. Mr. Mourdock's campaign was fueled by Tea Party groups and national conservative organizations that deemed Mr. Lugar too willing to compromise and poured millions of dollars into the campaign to defeat him.

headline.main: G.O.P. Voters Topple Lugar After 6 Terms

snippet: Edmond Demiraj’s case had reached the Supreme Court as he sought to prove that he feared for himself and his family if they were returned to their home country....
abstract: Federal government grants asylum to Albanian informer Edmond Demiraj, ending a case that had reached the Supreme Court as he sought to prove that he feared for himself and his family if they were returned to their home country. Photo (M)0
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON -- Ending a case that gained national attention after reaching the Supreme Court last year, the government granted asylum to an informer who said he feared execution if he were returned to his native Albania, his lawyers announced on Tuesday. The informer, Edmond Demiraj, had agreed to testify against an Albanian mobster charged with human smuggling a decade ago in exchange for what he said was a promise from federal prosecutors that he and his family would be kept safe. When the mobster, Bill Bedini, fled the country before his trial, the authorities deported Mr. Demiraj to Albania.

headline.main: Albanian Wins Bid For Asylum, Lawyers Say

snippet: North Carolina’s voters on Tuesday approved a constitutional amendment that bans same-sex marriage, joining 29 other states and the rest of the South....
abstract: North Carolina voters overwhelmingly approve a constitutional amendment that bans same-sex marriage, joining 29 other states and the rest of the South. Photo (M)
lead_paragraph: As expected, North Carolinians voted in large numbers on Tuesday for an amendment that would ban same-sex marriages, partnerships and civil unions, becoming the 30th state in the country and the last in the South to include a prohibition on gay marriage in the state constitution. About half a million people voted early, a record for a primary in the state, and turnout on Tuesday was unusually high as well. The amendment, which passed by a margin of more than 20 percentage points, was on the ballot along with other party primary races, some of which were closely contested.

headline.main: Ban on Gay Marriage Passes in North Carolina

snippet: Democratic leaders expressed alarm that George Soros’s $100 million plan to focus on grass-roots organizing would squander a chance to fend off an advertising onslaught from Republican groups....
abstract: Democratic leaders express alarm that George Soros's $100 million plan to focus on grass-roots organizing would duplicate a similar effort Pres Obama's campaign and squander a chance to fend off an advertising onslaught from Republican groups. (M)
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON -- Senior leaders of the Democratic Party expressed alarm on Tuesday that a $100 million plan by liberal donors to increase voter turnout would duplicate a similar effort by President Obama's campaign and squander a chance to fend off an advertising onslaught from Republican groups. Senator Harry Reid of Nevada, the majority leader, and other officials conveyed concern that Democratic candidates could be at a disadvantage if the contributors, many of whom had stayed on the sidelines of the 2012 campaign until now, decide not to spend money on television ads that push back against a torrent of attacks from conservative ''super PACS'' in the presidential election and Congressional races.

headline.main: Liberal Donors' Plan Worries Top Democrats

snippet: Republicans oppose the Democrats’ approach to paying for the program, which reduces some student loan interest rates....
abstract: Senate Republicans block consideration of a Democratic bill to prevent the doubling of some student loan interest rates, leaving the legislation in limbo less than two months before rates on subsidized federal loans are set to rise; Republicans oppose the Democrats' approach to paying for the program. Photos (M)2
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON -- Senate Republicans on Tuesday blocked consideration of a Democratic bill to prevent the doubling of some student loan interest rates, leaving the legislation in limbo less than two months before rates on subsidized federal loans are set to shoot upward. Along party lines, the Senate voted 52 to 45 on a key procedural motion, failing to reach the 60 votes needed to begin debating the measure. Senator Olympia J. Snowe, the moderate Republican from Maine who is retiring, voted present.

headline.main: Senate Republicans Block Bill to Avert Rise in Student Loan Rate

snippet: The work of President Obama’s media team, aided by Jim Margolis, is already on vivid display....
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON -- Forget hope and change. After months of planning, President Obama's media team has prepared an aggressive strategy to portray Mitt Romney as insensitive to the plight of working people and beholden to powerful interests. They have researched possible lines of attack and drafted language that can be dropped into an advertisement at a moment's notice.

headline.main: Aggressive Advertisements for Obama, at the Ready

byline.original: By JENNIFER STEINHAUER; Kitty Bennett and Monica Davey contributed reporting

snippet: Richard Mourdock, who defeated Senator Richard G. Lugar in Indiana’s Republican primary, has been committed to geology, motorcycling, marathons and a belief that only one party must prevail....
abstract: Man in the News profile of Richard E Mourdock, who defeated Indiana Republican Sen Richard G Lugar in the state's primary; Mourdock wants to cease the efforts at bipartisanship that defined the six-term tenure of Lugar and push for a more conservative agenda among Republicans in Congress. (M)
lead_paragraph: The man who deposed the Republican foreign policy conscience of the Senate is a 60-year-old homebody and former geologist who loves riding motorcycles, running marathons and thumbing through history books in bed. He is best known in political circles for trying -- unsuccessfully -- to block the auto bailout that saved thousands of jobs in Indiana, the state he seeks to represent in Congress. Should he prevail in November, Richard Earl Mourdock, who defeated Senator Richard G. Lugar in Indiana's Republican primary on Tuesday, might also replace Speaker John A. Boehner as the man most likely to cry during a floor speech.

headline.kicker: MAN IN THE NEWS | RICHARD MOURDOCK
headline.main: Many Pursuits, but Bipartisanship Isn't One of Them

snippet: A $1 billion city without residents will be developed in Lea County near Hobbs to help researchers test everything from intelligent traffic systems to automated washing machines and self-flushing toilets....
abstract: Researchers are developing a $1billion city without residents in Lea County, NM, near Hobbs to help test everything from intelligent traffic systems to automated washing machines and self-flushing toilets; research facility is seen as central to diversifying the area's economy. (S)
lead_paragraph: A $1 billion city without residents will be developed in Lea County near Hobbs, officials said Tuesday, to help researchers test everything from intelligent traffic systems and new wireless networks to automated washing machines and self-flushing toilets. Mayor Sam Cobb said the research facility, resembling an empty city, will be central to diversifying the area's economy. Pegasus Holdings and its New Mexico subsidiary, CITE Development, said Hobbs and Lea County beat out the city of Las Cruces for the Center for Innovation, Technology and Testing. The point of the town, to be developed on 15 square miles, is to test new technologies on existing infrastructure without interfering in everyday life. ''The only thing we won't be doing is destructive testing, blowing things up, I hope,'' said Bob Brumley, senior managing director of Pegasus Holdings.

headline.main: New Mexico: Lea County Is Chosen For $1 Billion Ghost Town For Research

snippet: North Carolina’s voters on Tuesday approved a constitutional amendment that bans same-sex marriage, joining 29 other states and the rest of the South....
lead_paragraph: North Carolina’s voters on Tuesday approved a constitutional amendment that bans same-sex marriage, joining 29 other states and the rest of the South.

headline.main: North Carolina Votes on Same-Sex Marriage Amendment

snippet: The sheer number of officers involved in a kickback scheme at the Baltimore Police Department stunned department veterans and civilians alike....
abstract: Sheer number of Baltimore police officers involved in a kickback scheme at an automobile body repair shop stuns department veterans and civilians alike; in the aftermath, Commissioner Frederick H Bealefeld III brings in Grayling G Williams, formerly of the Department of Homeland Security, to head the division charged with rooting out corruption. Photos (M)
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE -- Tucked behind a liquor store, opposite a flooring company, Majestic Body Shop was an unremarkable sight amid a blur of commercial properties just east of the city limits. But the police cars that always seemed to be parked at the repair shop caught the eyes of passing drivers. The F.B.I. noticed as well -- agents were videotaping Majestic and tapping its phone. What the investigation revealed was startling: a bribery racket suspected to involve kickbacks to dozens of Baltimore police officers.

headline.main: Baltimore Police Scandal Spotlights Leader's Fight To Root Out Corruption

snippet: State health officials closed an oyster harvesting area and ordered a recall of oysters taken there since April 26 after 14 people became ill with norovirus....
abstract: Louisiana health officials close a New Orleans oyster harvesting area and order a recall of oysters taken there since April 26 after 14 people became ill with norovirus. (S)
lead_paragraph: State health officials closed an oyster harvesting area and ordered a recall of oysters taken there since April 26 after 14 people became ill with norovirus. The closing, effective Tuesday, was expected to last at least 21 days, the amount of time it would take oysters to purge the virus. The recall includes shucked, frozen, breaded and processed oysters from an area of Terrebonne Parish. In addition to the New Orleans area, some oysters were shipped to Maryland, Texas and Georgia.

headline.main: Louisiana: Oysters Recalled After Illness

snippet: A prosecution witness in John Edwards’s federal corruption trial called him “a pathetic little man” and “evil” in e-mails with another witness, testimony in the trial revealed....
abstract: John Edwards's former longtime speechwriter Wendy Button testifies as a prosecution witness in the former senator's federal corruption trial on conspiracy and campaign finance violations; recounts Edwards's decision to come clean about the child from his extramarital affair. Photos (M)/
lead_paragraph: GREENSBORO, N.C. -- In August 2009, with a grand jury investigating former Senator John Edwards and the public still unclear about whether the affair he admitted to a year earlier had indeed produced a child, he struggled with how to finally tell the truth. To do that, he turned to Wendy Button, 43, his longtime speechwriter, who had drafted speeches for Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama when they were in the Senate. At the heart of the conversations between Ms. Button and Mr. Edwards, and at the heart of this trial, is whether Mr. Edwards knew more than he now claims about the money used to cover up the affair. According to Ms. Button's testimony on Tuesday, he did.

headline.main: Speechwriter Recounts Edwards's Decision to Come Clean About Child From Affair

snippet: The man accused of killing three relatives of the Oscar winner Jennifer Hudson did not take the stand, and his lawyers put on a mere 30-minute defense on Tuesday....
abstract: Defense rests after 30 minutes in the Chicago murder trial of William Balfour, who is accused of shooting actress Jennifer Hudson's mother, brother and nephew; Balfour, Hudson's former brother-in-law, did not take the stand. (S)/
lead_paragraph: The man accused of killing three relatives of the Oscar winner Jennifer Hudson did not take the stand, and his lawyers put on a mere 30-minute defense on Tuesday, calling two detectives in a bid to suggest they botched the 2008 investigation. The brief defense followed a two-week presentation by prosecutors, who called more than 80 witnesses as they sought to prove that the man, William Balfour, had shot the star's mother, brother and nephew in a jealous rage. Mr. Balfour, 30, is Ms. Hudson's former brother-in-law. A defense lawyer pressed one detective about a mistake he made in a report about the time a witness spotted a vehicle in which the nephew's body was found. The defense may use such errors to bolster its assertion that the police rushed to charge Mr. Balfour.

headline.main: Illinois: Defense Rests Quickly In Killings of Actress's Relatives

snippet: The Department of Defense has identified 1,947 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations....
abstract: Defense Department confirms deaths of four American service members in Afghanistan. (S)5
lead_paragraph: The Department of Defense has identified 1,947 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently: CHILDS, Gregory L., 38, Master Sgt., Army; Warren, Ark.; Defense Logistics Agency.

headline.main: Names of the Dead

snippet: A load of freight can make its way from Los Angeles to Chicago in 48 hours, then take 30 to get across the city....
abstract: Federal, state, local and industry officials are completing the early stages of a $3.2 billion railroad construction project that aims to improve traffic and decrease delays in Chicago, through which an estimated 1,300 freight and passenger trains pass every day; program will add overpasses, underpasses and 50 miles of new track. Photos, Map (M)
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO -- When it comes to rail traffic, Chicago is America's speed bump. Shippers complain that a load of freight can make its way from Los Angeles to Chicago in 48 hours, then take 30 hours to travel across the city. A recent trainload of sulfur took some 27 hours to pass through Chicago -- an average speed of 1.13 miles per hour, or about a quarter the pace of many electric wheelchairs.

headline.main: Freight Train Late in Charlotte? Blame Chicago

snippet: The state must deliver a man accused of murder to federal authorities, a federal appeals court in Boston ruled Monday....
abstract: Federal appeals court rules that Rhode Island must deliver Jason W Pleau, who is accused of robbing and killing a gas-station manager in 2010, to federal authorities; Gov Lincoln Chafee had refused to surrender the inmate in 2011, claiming that doing so could expose Pleau to the death penalty, which Rhode Island does not have. (S)a
lead_paragraph: The state must deliver a man accused of murder to federal authorities, a federal appeals court in Boston ruled Monday. Gov. Lincoln Chafee refused to surrender the inmate, Jason W. Pleau, in June 2011, when prosecutors wanted to try him in federal court. Mr. Chafee argued that doing so could expose Mr. Pleau to the death penalty, which Rhode Island does not have. Mr. Pleau is accused of robbing and killing a gas-station manager in 2010. Mr. Chafee has not said whether he will appeal the ruling.

headline.main: Rhode Island: State Told To Hand Over Murder Suspect

snippet: The former comptroller of Dixon pleaded not guilty on Monday to charges that she stole more than $53 million of the public’s money to finance a lavish lifestyle and create one of the nation’s foremost horse-breeding operations....
abstract: Rita Crundwell, the former comptroller of Dixon, Ill, pleads not guilty to charges that she stole more than $53 million of the public's money to finance a lavish lifestyle and create one of the nation's foremost horse-breeding operations. (S)o
lead_paragraph: The former comptroller of Dixon pleaded not guilty on Monday to charges that she stole more than $53 million of the public's money to finance a lavish lifestyle and create one of the nation's foremost horse-breeding operations. The woman, Rita Crundwell, refused to comment after leaving the federal courthouse in Rockford, where she pleaded not guilty to a single count of wire fraud, for which she could be sentenced up to 20 years in prison. Prosecutors say that since 1990, Ms. Crundwell, 58, diverted the money from Dixon, a city of 16,000 people, to an account she had set up for personal use. The authorities say she bought luxury homes and vehicles, and spent millions on her horse-breeding operation, RC Quarter Horses, which produced 52 world champions in exhibitions run by the American Quarter Horse Association. Prosecutors say her scheme unraveled only when a co-worker filling in while the comptroller was on vacation stumbled upon the secret bank account.

headline.main: Illinois: Not-Guilty Plea In $53 Million Theft

snippet: On the eve of a primary, Senator Richard G. Lugar’s campaign was by no means in retreat despite poll numbers that showed the support of only 38 percent of likely voters....
abstract: Sen Richard G Lugar, Republican of Indiana, is fighting for re-election to his seventh term in office on the eve of the Republican primary after poll numbers show that he has the support of only 38 percent of likely voters; his opponent is Richard E Mourdock, who is receiving support from national conservative groups. (M)
lead_paragraph: In the final, frenzied days of campaigning, Richard G. Lugar, who has won six previous elections to the United States Senate, has not exactly soft-pedaled the size of his challenge in the Indiana Republican primary on Tuesday. ''Register your vote because if you do not, I may not be able to continue serving you,'' Mr. Lugar said bluntly at a news conference late last week. ''So at this point, help, I would say, is very important -- that people get there and get there fast.''

headline.main: On the Eve Of Voting, A Senator Fights On

snippet: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s effort to subordinate his own voice to the broader enterprise has been a struggle, especially for a man who delights in speaking bluntly....
abstract: Vice President Joseph R Biden Jr, whose blunt style is often a flashpoint for criticism, has worked to restrain his ego in the service of his support role, and Pres Obama has come to appreciate Biden's loyalty, tested over a whip-lashing term; still, some officials close to Obama worry that Biden may become less restrained in sharing his personal positions in the service of his own political ambitions; Biden has not ruled out making a run for president in 2016. Photo (M)
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON -- As President Obama reviewed the comedy routine he was to deliver at the recent White House Correspondents' Association dinner, one joke struck him as too hot. It suggested he might dump Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. from the ticket. ''Four years ago, I chose Joe Biden as my running mate,'' Mr. Obama was to say, according to people familiar with early drafts of the planned remarks. ''Four years later, I'm almost positive I'm going with Joe again.'' He would then affect an exaggerated wink for the audience. But the president instructed his speechwriters to cut the line, figuring it would only inflame speculation from Beltway busybodies about his vice president's standing.

headline.main: For a Blunt Biden, an Uneasy Supporting Role

snippet: A federal court on Monday reversed its demand that the Veterans Affairs Department overhaul its mental health care system....
abstract: Federal appeals court reverses earlier demand that the Veterans Affairs Department overhaul its mental health care system, saying that any such changes need to be ordered by Congress or the president. (M)9
lead_paragraph: A federal court on Monday reversed its demand that the Veterans Affairs Department overhaul its mental health care system. A special 11-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit said that any such changes need to be ordered by Congress or the president. A three-judge panel of the same court ordered the V.A. in 2011 to ensure that suicidal veterans are seen immediately, among other changes. It found the department's ''unchecked incompetence'' in handling the flood of post-traumatic stress disorder and other mental health claims was unconstitutional. The new decision said courts are powerless to carry out the fixes sought by two veterans groups that sued the department in 2007, saying that hundreds of thousands of veterans had to wait an average of four years to fully receive the mental health benefits owed them.

headline.main: California: Call For Veterans Agency Fixes Is Reversed

snippet: A final House vote this Thursday amounts to a Republican bet that voters will reward the party for its tough-love priorities on spending....
abstract: Republican-led House will lay bare the choice between social programs and Pentagon spending when it votes on budget legislation to slice $261 billion from social service programs over the next decade to stave off more than $50 billion in military spending cuts scheduled to take effect in 2013. Photo (M)a
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON -- The Republican-led House this week will lay bare the choice between social programs and Pentagon spending in an age of austerity when it takes up legislation to slice $261 billion from food stamps, Medicaid, social services and other programs for struggling Americans over the next decade to stave off more than $50 billion in military spending cuts scheduled to take effect next year. The House Budget Committee on Monday took up budget bills passed out of six different committees last month, packaged them and sent them to the full House as one bill on a party-line vote. A separate bill, also approved by the committee, would formally lift the threat of automatic Pentagon cuts next year.

headline.main: House Bill Offers Aid Cuts To Save Military Spending

snippet: As two Obama officials all but endorsed same-sex marriage, new pressure was placed on the president to take a definitive stance on the issue....
abstract: Pres Obama faces renewed pressure to take a clear stand on same-sex marriage despite the unpredictable consequences it may have for his re-election bid; push comes as North Carolina is set to vote on a constitutional amendment banning it and Colorado advocates of civil unions are seeking to push a measure through the State Legislature; Education Secretary Arne Duncan voices his support for same-sex marriage. Photo (M)
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON -- A day after his vice president's expansive comments all but endorsing same-sex marriage, President Obama faced renewed pressure on Monday to complete his ''evolving'' on the issue and to take a clear stand despite the unpredictable consequences for his re-election bid. The push on the issue extended to other administration officials even as White House aides insisted that the remarks of Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. on a Sunday television talk show were no different from what Mr. Obama has said in the past.

headline.main: 2 Bills and Comments By Officials Stir Debate Over Same-Sex Unions

snippet: Under investigation is $725,000 of the $7 million the heiress Rachel Mellon had given John Edwards since 2004....
abstract: Witnesses for the prosecution in the corruption trial of former Sen John Edwards testify that Edwards routinely asked heiress Rachel Mellon for donations for needs beyond his political campaigns; defense lawyers argue instead that Mellon's money, which Edwards used to cover up his affair with Rielle Hunter, was never intended to be used for his 2008 presidential election campaign but was just a gift from a friend. Photo (M)
lead_paragraph: GREENSBORO, N.C. -- Defense lawyers for former Senator John Edwards spent much of the morning trying to show that money from the heiress Rachel Mellon used to cover up Mr. Edwards's affair was not intended to influence the election but was just a gift from a friend. ''She liked him as a person,'' Alexander Forger, who handles Ms. Mellon's finances, said under questioning. ''It wasn't because he was running for elective office.''

headline.main: Patron's Contributions and Their Intent Are Focus at Edwards Trial

byline.original: By SABRINA TAVERNISE; Joe Drape contributed reporting

snippet: The police interviewed more people in the killing of a groom whose body was found hours after the Kentucky Derby....
abstract: Police in Louisville, Ky, interview people in the killing of groom Adan Fabian Perez, whose body was found at the Churchill Downs racetrack hours after the conclusion of the Kentucky Derby; no suspects are named. Photo (M)d
lead_paragraph: The murder of a groom at Churchill Downs remained a mystery on Monday, as the police in Louisville, Ky., interviewed people they thought might know about the death but did not name any suspects. The groom, Adan Fabian Pérez, was found dead in Barn No. 8 shortly before dawn on Sunday, just hours after the conclusion of the Kentucky Derby. He was working for the trainer Cecil Borel, the brother of the jockey Calvin Borel, said Richard Brown, a spokesman for the Kentucky Horse Racing Commission.

headline.main: Few Clues in Killing of Groom at Churchill Downs

snippet: The president’s proposal to lawmakers packages job creation and mortgage relief ideas he has called for in the past....
abstract: Pres Obama is expected to outline a five-point economic to-do list for Congress that packages several of his ideas for job creation, business tax cuts and mortgage relief. (M)
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON -- With a polarized Congress already on the defensive, President Obama on Tuesday will outline a five-point ''to do'' list for lawmakers that packages job creation and mortgage relief ideas he has proposed before, administration officials say. Mr. Obama will present the election-year list during a visit to a university science complex in Albany. The components of his challenge to Congress -- and to the Republican-led House in particular -- will be a feature of his appearances throughout the spring, aides said.

headline.main: Obama Hands Congress An Economic 'To Do' List

snippet: Major donors are preparing to inject $100 million into independent groups that plan to avoid the type of advertising campaigns financed by conservatives....
abstract: George Soros is among the major liberal donors preparing to inject up to $100 million into independent groups to aid Democrats' chances in 2012 elections; instead of going head to head with the conservative super PACs and outside groups that have flooded the presidential and Congressional campaigns with negative advertising, the donors are focusing on grass-roots organizing, voter registration and Democratic turnout. Photo (M)
lead_paragraph: After months on the sidelines, major liberal donors including the financier George Soros are preparing to inject up to $100 million into independent groups to aid Democrats' chances this fall. But instead of going head to head with the conservative ''super PACs'' and outside groups that have flooded the presidential and Congressional campaigns with negative advertising, the donors are focusing on grass-roots organizing, voter registration and Democratic turnout. The departure from the conservatives' approach, which helped Republicans wrest control of the House in 2010, partly reflects liberal donors' objections to the Supreme Court's Citizens United decision, which paved the way for super PACs and unbridled campaign spending.

headline.main: Liberal Donors Will Spend Big On Grass Roots

snippet: House sponsors of the bill, which passed the Senate last week, were trying to win approval before the legislative session ends on Wednesday....
lead_paragraph: DENVER -- Supporters of a bill that would allow civil unions for same-sex couples in Colorado were hopeful on Monday that the legislation, buoyed by the support of key Republican lawmakers who broke party ranks, would pass before the legislative session ended this week. The bill, which has already cleared the State Senate, passed a pair of House committees last week capping a whirlwind few days where its fate was uncertain.

headline.main: Colorado Same-Sex Union Bill Gains G.O.P. Supporters

snippet: A 92-year-old woman who acknowledged selling kits to help people commit suicide has been sentenced to five years probation for failing to file federal tax returns....
abstract: Sharlotte Hydorn, an elderly California woman who acknowledged selling kits to help people commit suicide, is sentenced to five years probation for failing to file federal tax returns; conviction is part of plea deal she reached with federal prosecutors, who chose to prosecute her for tax evasion because they felt it was the best way to stop her. (S)
lead_paragraph: A 92-year-old woman who acknowledged selling kits to help people commit suicide has been sentenced to five years' probation for failing to file federal tax returns and was ordered to not participate in assisting suicides. The conviction of Sharlotte Hydorn was part of a plea deal reached with federal prosecutors after investigators raided her home last year in El Cajon, east of San Diego. She will not be charged in state court with involvement in six suicides. Assistant United States Attorney Peter J. Mazza said the government had opted to prosecute Ms. Hydorn, a retired schoolteacher, for tax evasion because they felt it was the best way to stop her. There is no federal law regarding assisted suicides. Prosecutors say she sold at least 1,300 kits for between $40 and $60 each. Investigators determined that the kits were sold to at least 50 people in San Diego County since 2007 and that 4 of those people last year used the kits to commit suicide. None were terminally ill, according to investigators. In court, Ms. Hydorn admitted she made $66,717 in 2010 and paid no taxes on that.

headline.main: California: Seller of Suicide Kits Accepts Plea Deal

snippet: Julia Trigg Crawford and her family have had multiple visits from TransCanada representatives regarding land rights to their farm in Sumner, Tex....
abstract: Julia Trigg Crawford, farmer in Sumner, Tex, who had initially refused TransCanada Corp the rights to her land to let the planned Keystone XL pipeline cross through, discovers that her property has been condemned and a lease awarded to the company without her consent; she is appealing the condemnation, which is legal under a state law that allows certain private companies to use right of eminent domain to force landowners to let pipelines through. Photo, Map (M)
lead_paragraph: SUMNER, Tex. -- When the TransCanada men first came, Julia Trigg Crawford said, they were polite. They offered money. Seven thousand dollars to let the Keystone XL pipeline cross her family's 600-acre farm on its way from the Alberta tar sands to the refineries on the Gulf Coast. This was nothing new. Her grandfather bought the land, in northeast Texas, about a two-hour drive from Dallas and a quarter mile from the Oklahoma border, in 1948 and started growing wheat, corn and soy. Since then, pipeline companies have tried to lease rights to cross it many times. The Crawfords always managed to persuade them to find a way around their property.

headline.main: An Old Texas Tale Retold: the Farmer vs. the Oil Company

byline.original: By MICHAEL BARBARO; Mark Landler, Brian Knowlton and Jonathan Weisman contributed reporting

snippet: After the vice president’s comments, the White House clarified that he was not articulating a change in policy....
abstract: Comments made by Vice Pres Joseph R Biden Jr backing same-sex marriage send White House aids scrambling to clarify that Biden was not articulating an official change in policy; reaction from the Obama administration highlights it unease over the subject. Photo (M)/
lead_paragraph: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. said on Sunday that he was ''absolutely comfortable'' with same-sex marriages and was heartened by their growing acceptance across the country, a position that moves well beyond the ''evolving'' views that President Obama has said he holds on the issue. The comments, which aides described as the off-the-cuff views of a vice president not known for fidelity to a script, sent the White House scrambling to clarify that Mr. Biden was not articulating an official change in policy, a reaction that highlighted the administration's unease over the subject.

headline.main: A Scramble as Biden Backs Same-Sex Marriage
